To the Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,-

Enclosed find report of Mr. Johnson for his services as teacher at Little Grand Rapids for the summer months. You will notice that the average attendance during the quarter was 16.8. This is a very good showing indeed.

I may say that I have agreed to pay Mr. Johnson $250.00 for his services, and we will leave it to the judgment of the Department as to whether this is a fair remuneration for the work done. If the Department approve of it or any part of it a cheque can be sent to the Methodist Mission Rooms, Toronto.

Yours sincerely,

J. Ferrier

ENC.

[Handwritten note:]
pay at rate of $500 per year

CANADA

Pool Copy
October 27, 1922.

MEMO FOR FILE:

Mr. Agent Latulippe reports that W. J. Hope, Teacher of the Indian Day School at Little Grand Rapids, has informed him that there were no children in attendance at the school on the first of September and that he does not expect any until the time of the next annuity payment.
Ottawa, November 14, 1922.

Sir,-

The September quarter return of the Little Grand Rapids Indian Day School, signed by you, has just been received. This return states that the school was open 45 days.

The Department cannot understand why school was in operation for this length of time, owing to the fact that it was only opened on July 24th, last, and a recent letter from you stated that there were no children in attendance on the 1st of September and that you did not expect any further attendance until the time of next annuity payment.

The Department would like you to report fully on this school, stating definitely for what period of time it was open during the past summer and also for how many days you consider the teacher should be paid.

Kindly give this matter your immediate attention in order that a cheque for the amount due can be sent.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

H. O. Latulippe, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Belkirk, MAN.
Sir.—Dear Mr. Ferrier,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 14th instant, NO.125-12-3, in reply I beg to say that on Saturday last I made a special trip to East St. Peters to interview the teacher, Mr. W.J. Hope, so as to furnish you with a definite report in regard to the Little Grand Rapids Indian Day School.

Mr. Hope stated that he had made an error in reporting to this office that this school was closed the 1st September, that he meant the latter part of September, he claims that he taught till about the 20th of September, but did not have the school register with him, and had then to return to Selkirk on account of ill health. Due to his physical condition, the Rev. Mr. Niddrie was good enough to fill in his school returns, and he considers that he is entitled to two month's salary.

I also inquired of him what he meant by stating that the children of the Little Grand Rapids Band would not return until the time of next annuity payment, to this he replied that he was informed by some of the Indians that they would return with their families from their hunting about the first part of June, after the rivers clears up, he also stated that when he left there was two families and they were going away shortly.

I visited this school on the 26th July and 4th of August last and taking into consideration that the children had not attended school previously, I consider that the results were quite satisfactory. I sincerely regret that there was a misunderstanding between Mr. Hope and myself in regard to my first report and hoping that this one will be satisfactory.

Russell T. Ferrier, Esq.
Supt. Of Indian Education
Department Of Indian Affairs
Ottawa, Ont.

Your obedient servant

Ottawa, August 20th, 1924.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge your letter of the 14th instant, with reference to the Little Grand Rapids Indian Day School. I have noted that the members of the Band are preparing a log school and residence, and that you recommend the appointment of Miss Moore who has taken Grade XI at the Selkirk Collegiate.

In reply I have to inform you that Miss Moore's appointment, at a salary of $5.00 per teaching day, is approved. No bonus will be allowed in her case. Payment of salary will be made upon receipt from your office of certified quarterly returns showing the number of pupils in attendance and the number of days school was kept open. Rev. T. Ferrier, Superintendent of Methodist Indian Schools, is being informed.

You will receive another communication with reference to the building activity.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

H. O. Latulippe, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Selkirk, Man.

Little Grand Rapids
Via Breskien, Man.
July 25th 1925.

Office in Charge
Dept. Indian Affairs
Octave

Dear Sir,

Being teacher of Little Grand Rapids School (which is under the jurisdiction of the Methodist Church and in charge Mr. Ferrier of Brandon) I would like very much if you could inform me as to what I am entitled to in the matter of salary which is in the hands of your Department.

I have been teaching school since October 6th 1924 till June 30th 1925, a total of [73] school days.

Kindly let me know if I am paid per day or an annual salary and at what rate.

Yours faithfully,
Minnie Mohr,
School Teacher.
Little Grand Rapids
Via Bresk Nov. 1925.

Ottawa, August 4, 1925.

Madam:

In reply to your letter of the 25th ultimo, I have to say that it was arranged with Rev. T. Ferrier, Superintendent of Methodist Indian Schools, to allow you $3.00 a day for the periods you taught the Little Grand Rapids Indian Day School. Since last October, the following payments have been made to the Methodist Church:

December quarter - 56 days .... $168.
March " - 62 " .... 186.
June " - 55 " .... 165.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Miss Mima Moar,
Little Grand Rapids,
Via Berens River, Man.
Ottawa, Sept. 10, 1925.

Reverend Sir:

In reply to your letter of the 2nd instant, I have to say that the appointment of John James Everett as teacher of the Little Grand Rapids Indian Day School, at a salary of $4.00 per teaching day, is approved. Please advise the Department the exact date on which Mr. Everett commenced duties at this school.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Rev. T. Perrier,
Superintendent,
Methodist Indian Schools,
Brandon, Man.
Dear Sir,

I beg to submit herewith the September return of the United Church Indian Day School of Little Grand Rapids Reserve, just received from Rev. J.W. Niddrie.

I may say that I have not been advised by the Department that Mr. John James Everett had been appointed teacher of this school.

Your obedient servant

The Secretary
Department Of Indian Affairs
Ottawa, Ont.

Indian Agent

Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY

Re: Little Grand Rapids U.C.
Indian Day School, No. 533.

Mr. J.H. Clark will not be in charge of this school during the coming academic year. To succeed him the Department has approved the appointment of Mr. H.A. Dusick at a salary of $100.00 a teaching month, plus bonus. He will re-open the school on June 1, 1943, and it will continue in operation to February 20, 1944. Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY

Re: Little Grand Rapids U.C.
Indian Day School, No. 523.

In memorandum of May 24 you were advised that Mr. N.A. Dueck would begin duties at the above-mentioned school on June 1 at a salary of $100.00 a teaching month, plus bonus. Mr. Dueck did not open the school on June 1 and no payment of salary should be made to him until you hear further from this office.

MEMORANDUM:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY

Re: Little Grand Rapids I.C.
Indian Day School, No. 583.

I desire to refer you to my memoranda of May 24 and June 24, in connection with the appointment of Mr. N.A. Dueck as teacher of the above-named school. I am now definitely informed that Mr. Dueck began duties on July 33, 1943, at a salary of $100.00 a teaching month, plus bonus. His employment will be continuous to June 30, 1944.

Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY

Re: Little Grand Rapids U.C.
Indian Day School, No. 583.

It has now been decided to take the annual two months' holidays at this school during the months of April and May. Consequently Mr. Dusek's services will be continuous only to March 31, 1944. No payment should be made to him for the months of April and May.

Your letter #125-12-1 dated Augt.11/24 has been received.

While I was at Little Grand Rapids, on 19th July, paying Annuity money, the school question was thoroughly gone into at a Meeting of the Band. The members of the Band had taken out 70 logs and hauled them to a site in the centre of the Reserve, to build a school 20 X 30 ft., with addition, for teacher's residence 12 X 20 ft.

The only stipulation made was that the Department should furnish rations to the Indians who worked on the job, they furnishing the labour free. The rationing would mean approximately $100.00.

The school has been held in an old log building, built on the H.B.C. land, for which the Department furnished windows and stove in 1922. These could be used in the new building. Roofing, nails, locks and hinges would be required at a cost of $35.00. A blackboard and the usual supply of books and stationery would be required.

Miss Moar has been a pupil of the Selkirk Collegiate and has taken her Grade XI, and I think would be well qualified to fill the position.

Kindly let me know if you will give authority for expenditure, for rations and material, asked for.

Sir,

Referring to your letter, #125-12-5, dated August 20/24, with reference to the Little Grand Rapids Indian Day School, I beg to inform you that when I was at that Reserve last August, I inspected the new building, in course of construction. This is a log building, 24 x 24, with 10 ft. walls, roofed with small hewed spruce rails. A year ago they received roofing and hardware to the amount of $35.00, and also rations for the Indians working on the building, which amounted to about $60.00.

I found they were still short on material to complete the building, and they asked for further assistance from the Department, of the following:

- 3 Rolls Roofing.
- 4 windows, 6 x 10, 12 light.
- 1 door
- 300 lbs. lime.

The approximate cost of above material would be $30.00, and I would recommend that this expenditure be granted to enable them to complete the building.

Kindly let me know your decision as soon as possible, to allow me to forward the material before navigation closes about the middle of October.

Your obedient servant,

Sir;-

I beg to submit the following explanations in reference to attached voucher NO.41/27 for $131.45 in favor of the Hudson's Bay Company, at Little Grand Rapids.

In your letter NO.125-12-5, dated 20th August, 1925, you authorized the Agent, Mr. Latulippe to supply rations to the Indians who were working on the new log buildings, for school and teachers residence at Little Grand Rapids Reserve, the amount not to exceed $100.00. This was taken up and went through in voucher No.121/25, dated 15th Feb., 1925. Last summer when at Little Grand Rapids, the building was not finished and Mr. Latulippe authorized the rationing of those working so that the school would be completed by the fall and ready for school opening. None of the Indians received wages for their work only rations were issued to those who were willing to give a helping hand.

The other item, $47.45 included in this voucher is for rations supplied to Wm. Meekis, No.63 Deer Lake Band, who was a patient at Dynevor Hospital, and on being discharged was on his way home and was stranded at L. Grand Rapids on account of the early freeze up.

Dear Sir:

Sir:

I beg to enclose requisition for supplies for mid-day meal for the pupils at Little Grand Rapids Protestant Day School. Belkirk, Man. 29th August, 1928

I beg to advise you that the teacher, Mr. L. Schuetze, of Little Grand Rapids Protestant Day School called at this office yesterday, reporting that on August 12th a severe hail storm broke over that district, breaking 21 panes of glass and tearing the rubberoid off the roof of the school. As the repairing of this damage was necessary I have shipped today the glass and 3 rolls of tar paper, and trust this will meet with your approval.

Mr. Schuetze also asked for the following material etc. for this school, which if granted he would team in, in winter, from Atheson Island.

Sir:

I beg to enclose requisition for school material, school supplies and supplies for mid-day meal, for Little Grand Rapids Protestant Indian Day School.

The school material and mid-day meal supplies are the same as in former years.

The school supplies include 30 single desks. There are no desks in this school, the pupils using homemade benches of the very roughest description. They are badly needed, but the freight charges from Berens River to Little Grand Rapids (by canoe) amounts to $5.00 per cwt., which makes purchases for articles of this kind almost prohibitive.

Ottawa, April 13, 1935.

Sir:

The Department is in receipt of your vouchers Nos. 233-35 for $43.61 covering the cost of freighting supplies by aeroplane from Berens River to Little Grand Rapids. This account is being paid, but the Department cannot understand why it was necessary to have the supplies shipped by aeroplane.

The purchase of midday meal supplies and other articles was authorized by official letter of September 17th. You submitted an account from F. Barresford dated September 24th. You later submitted an account dated October 31st from the Hudson's Bay Company covering the cost of freighting school supplies from Berens River to Little Grand Rapids. This account included one sack of beans, and it is noted that the account from the Aeroplane Company also included this item.

Please let me know why all the supplies were not sent forward at the freight rate of $3.50 a hundred. Shipping supplies by aeroplane is very expensive, and, in this case, the charges for shipping them amounted to more than the cost of the articles. There is no necessity for incurring such heavy expenditure if you apply early in July or August for authority to purchase the supplies necessary for outlying schools.

The Department will expect to have a full explanation regarding your reasons for delaying the shipment to Little Grand Rapids School.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

A. Irwin, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Selkirk, Man.
Sir:

Replying to your letter No.125-12-5 of 13th instant, re-freighting of supplies to Little Grand Rapids I wish to state that my letter of 30th August was replied to on 17th September authorizing the purchase of mid-day meal supplies for Little Grand Rapids.

The order was immediately placed with Mr. Fred Berresford and left Selkirk by the next steamer leaving Selkirk for Berens River.

By this time ice had formed in places on the Berens River and neither the Hudson's Bay Company or the Indians would undertake the trip to Little Grand Rapids with canoes.

Sometime later the Hudson's Bay Company arranged to have a shipment of their own supplies taken to Little Grand Rapids by aeroplane and in this shipment the mid-day meal supplies for the United Church Indian Day School were included.

The account submitted on 31st October from the Hudson's Bay Company was for freighting school supplies including one sack beans from Berens River to Little Grand Rapids for the R.C. Day School, whilst the school supplies including one sack beans shipped by plane, was for the United Church Day School at Little Grand Rapids.

Your obedient servant,

Andrew Irwin,

Ottawa, January 29, 1937.

Dear Sir:

The Department is advised that a quantity of the biscuits supplied for use at the Little Grand Rapids United Church Indian Day School have become mouldy. It would appear that these biscuits were packed in the boxes while still warm.

I have to request that you will advise the Department how many boxes of these biscuits have become mouldy and state the weight, if possible. When we receive this information, regarding the quantity of damaged biscuits, the matter will be taken up with the firm who supplied them, with a view to having them replace the quantity of damaged biscuits. Please give this matter your prompt attention and furnish the information requested. You should address your reply to the Secretary, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

L. L. Schuetze, Esq.,
Teacher,
United Church Indian Day School,
Little Grand Rapids, Man.
Dear Sir-

In reply to Yours of the 29th January which I received yesterday on Sunday.

It is very hard to state the exact amount of Biscuits spoiled, there were about 5 boxes in all so far, but only one of them was so bad that we had to throw away about half.

Each box has 25 lbs Net Weight, I would judge that about 50 lbs were spoiled altogether.

Of course the balance of these boxes were not very tasty either, as the Kiddies complained about them.

Trusting that this Information is satisfactory

I remain Yours truly

We quote the following letter just received from Mr. Scheutze:-

United Church Indian Day School,
Berens River, Man:
May 26th, 1939:

Dear Mr. Hoey:

A considerable time ago you advised me that it would be permissible for a Day School teacher to communicate directly with you regarding any phase of his work; I take the liberty now of availing myself of the opportunity presented by your most considerate attitude.

I shall be leaving Berens River on or about the first of July to take over the Mission at Little Grand Rapids; here I have been teacher only but there I shall be teacher and missionary and assume certain duties from the Indian Office at Selkirk. Mr. Luther Schmetz, our present Missionary here; and my co-worker came to us last year from Little Grand Rapids where he was Missionary etc.; for IO or more years; he has told me of the need for a new school-building there.

As it is now too late to consider making a request for anew building I wish to ask you for the authority to spend $300 in erecting a lean-to to the present building and carrying out any repairs to the old building. As the school building is two miles by water from the Mission House, serving hot lunches necessitates cooking in the morning, transporting by canoe with us at 8 AM; rearming in class room at noon, washing and eating and cleaning up after all in the same room. With a lean-to, washing, cooking, eating, and cleaning up after could all be done by senior pupils under teacher's surveillance.

Our Indian Agent will be here in June and at L:G:R: soon in July where I shall see him; however I would like very much to have the work underway as soon as I get up there in order to insure its completion by the end of August; this explains in part my reason for wishing you to take action directly.

The $300.00 would equip as well as erect the lean-to proposed.

Trusting to hear from you at your convenience:

Yours Truly,

[Signature]

Teacher:

R:A: Hoey Esq.,
Supt: Of Welfare And Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa:

P:S: I have been to L:G:R: at different times and have seen the conditions:

P:S: This building erected last year is a wonderful place; it is just about everything a Day School should be: We demolished the old building and divided the materials among 40 families; Empire Day we had 300 people here to attend our Sports; Our prizes amounted to $60; Our average attendance since moving into this building has been well over 30.

C.O.S.
AIR MAIL

Ottawa, June 16, 1939.

Dear Mr. Street:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 26th ultimo, in which you intimate that it is your intention to take charge of the Little Grand Rapids Indian Day School and Mission early in July.

I note with interest your request for authority to spend approximately $300.00 in the erection of a lean-to to the present school building. I may state that the existing regulations governing the expenditure of departmental appropriations make it almost impossible to comply with a request of this kind. For example, all lumber, building supplies, etc., must be purchased by the Departmental Purchasing Agent. Certain exceptions are made in outlying districts, but these exceptions apply to cases that have been carefully reviewed and submitted to the Purchasing Agent for his approval.

There is nothing on file here to indicate the condition of the Little Grand Rapids school. It is just possible that if the school is in a dilapidated or semi-dilapidated condition, it would be very unwise to spend even the sum of $300.00 in repairing it this year. It might be better, in view of all the circumstances, to apply for the erection of a new school, on the understanding that construction would take place next year.

We have in the 1939-40 estimates a comparatively small sum for the upkeep and repair of school -

Colin D. Street, Esq.,
Teacher,
United Church Indian Day School,
Berens River, Manitoba.

May I suggest to you that you communicate with either the Indian Agent, Mr. McPherson, or Inspector Hamilton, asking either of them to forward to the Department a recommendation as to what should be done at Little Grand Rapids. It is my understanding that Mr. McPherson has recently visited the district. If such is the case, he ought to be in a position to make a recommendation with respect to the repairs that may be required at the Little Grand Rapids school.

June 26th, 1939:

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I have received your letter of the 16th for which I thank you. Treaty was paid here a week ago. Both Mr. Hamilton and Mr. McPherson visited our school. Your letter came the next day after Mr. Hamilton had departed for the north. However he told me there was a possibility that he would be at L:G:R: for Treaty next month.

We expect to leave here by plane on the fifth of next month so will be in Little Grand Rapids a week or so before Treaty is paid. I shall at that time ask either the Inspector or Agent to forward to you the necessary recommendations re the school building.

Considering the probability of a new school there for next year I shall reduce my requests as for the present building to a minimum.

We expect Treaty to be paid at L:G:R: about the middle of July.

Selkirk, Man., August 1, 1939.

Dear Sir:

I have just returned from making the Annuity Payment at Little Grand Rapids, at which Reserve I took up the question of a new school for the United Church. The school in use now is in such poor condition that I would suggest that the Department allow Mr. Street to get permission from the Church officials to use the Church for a school during the Winter months.

I have discussed with Mr. Street the possibility of making repairs to the old school, but in my opinion it would be only a waste of money to repair this old building.

Mr. Street suggests that a school 26' x 42' be built to accommodate the pupils, he also suggests that a dining hall 16' x 32' be built. It is my opinion, that owing to the excessive freight rates on materials shipped into this district, that he could get along nicely if a new school only, were built.

The Roman Catholic school on this Reserve is also in very poor condition. Here again, the building is old and in such condition that any repairs made would not help much and would be only a waste of money. A new building 36' x 22' should be built to replace the old building in use at the present time.

If new schools are to be built on this Reserve, the materials would have to be shipped in during the Winter season, either by tractor or by horses. I will advise the Department further as soon as I am able to find out what the freight rate would be on materials shipped either from Berens River or from Riverton.

Ottawa, August 11, 1939.

Re: Little Grand Rapids Indian Day School.

Dear Sir:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the first instant and to thank you for the information contained therein.

In the 1939-40 estimates provision was made for the construction of a United Church Indian day school at Little Grand Rapids, at an estimated cost of $5,000.

If, as you suggest, it is impossible to proceed with the actual construction of this school during the present fiscal year, action should be taken to purchase the materials necessary for the construction of this building. If you consider it inadvisable to provide basement accommodation, I am personally of the opinion that, in addition to the regular schoolroom, accommodation should be provided for vocational training or the serving of midday meals. It is just possible that the addition I have in mind could serve both purposes. I have learned from experience that it is almost impossible to expect a teacher to undertake vocational instruction and provide noonday meals in the regular classroom. However, this is a matter that you might discuss with Inspector Hamilton.

I am particularly anxious that consideration should be given immediately to the purchase of lumber and other materials necessary for the construction of the building itself. It is highly desirable that these supplies should be purchased and paid for from this year's appropriation.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

E. McPherson, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Selkirk, Man.

Dear Sir:

Re: Little Grand Rapids U.C. Indian Day School

With reference to your letter of August 11th, File 125-12-5.

I regret the delay in answering your letter, but I have just received the information as to the cost of hauling freight to Little Grand Rapids.

I have a price from George Leyound, Matheson Island as follows:
5¢ per lb. on cement, windows, etc.
$80.00 per thousand board feet of lumber.

The above prices are for hauling freight from Matheson Island to the site of the school at Little Grand Rapids. There would be an additional freight charge by the Selkirk Navigation Company of .25¢ per 100 lbs of cement, windows, etc., and of $3.00 per thousand board feet of lumber, from Selkirk to Matheson Island.

In regard to accommodation for vocational training, etc. Due to the rocky nature of the ground, it would not be possible to put in a basement. Therefore, if this accommodation is required, an addition to the building would have to be built.

As it would be necessary to have this material shipped to Matheson Island before freeze up, I cannot over-emphasize the need for immediate action if this building is to be built this Winter or next Spring.

The shipping season closes here the first week in October.

I am enclosing herewith on form 37½, the list of material required for the school building itself and also the list of material for the addition for vocational training. I have also estimated the cost of hauling this material from Selkirk direct to Little Grand Rapids. We have been unable to get even an approximate bid for carpenter work for constructing this building.

Trusting that this information may be of some value to you, I am,

Very truly yours,

E. McPherson,
Indian Agent.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER:

Provision has been made in the 1938-40 estimates for the construction of an Indian day school at Little Grand Rapids, Clandeboye agency, province of Manitoba, at an estimated cost of $5,000.

The Indian day school operated at Little Grand Rapids is at this date in such poor condition that permission has been granted by the church officials to use the church for school purposes during the coming winter months. I regret to state that a great deal of delay has been experienced in making provision for the construction of this school. The Indian agent was absent for a time on a treaty paying trip and has taken a full month to secure information requested in respect to lumber, freight costs, etc. The agent now estimates that the cost of building material and freight will amount to approximately $3,500 and has sent forward a requisition describing this building material in detail.

In view of the lateness of the season, I recommend, subject to the approval of the Minister, that Inspector Hamilton be authorized to call for tenders for the supply of this material and that the construction of the school be undertaken this Fall, if possible, under the direction of a capable foreman-carpenter.

Director

Dear Sir:

In reply to Department letter 125-12-5, dated September 7th, 1939, I wish to report that I took this matter up with Mr. McPherson and a letter went forward direct from his office dated September 12th.

I would draw your attention to the expensive freight rate, especially from Matheson Island -- $5.00 per cwt. on cement and $60.00 a thousand on lumber. This makes the cement cost approximately $6.45 per cwt. and lumber approximately $115.00 per thousand, F.O.B. destination. I am sure these prices make building, especially in these times, prohibitive. I have seen many a good log school throughout our white districts and if logs are available they should meet the need at this point. These people are trappers and hunters, consequently the attendance will be very irregular, as the women and children usually accompany the father to the trap lines. I would be glad to know what action the Department takes.

Yours very truly,

A. G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Manitoba.

Re: Little Grand Rapids School

Dear Sir:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 15th instant, in which you intimate that consideration should be given to the desirability of constructing the Indian day school at Little Grand Rapids with logs that might be secured in the immediate district.

I am of the opinion that not only the Little Grand Rapids school but a number of schools in the outlying districts of the Dominion should be of log construction. No doubt, you are aware that the provincial government of Manitoba have built a number of such schools in recent years. I regret to state, however, that it will not be possible to cancel the orders that are no doubt already placed for the purchase of lumber for the school at Little Grand Rapids. The records here indicate that immediately following the receipt of Mr. McPherson's letter of September 12 the Purchasing Agent was asked to proceed with the purchase of the lumber outlined in the requisitions attached to Mr. McPherson's communication. It was my understanding that tenders were called for by air mail and arrangements made for the immediate delivery of these supplies. The Department was particularly anxious -

anxious that these supplies should be purchased and delivered at Little Grand Rapids by winter freight. It is my hope that the time at your disposal will enable you to give a certain amount of thought to the desirability of constructing Indian day schools with logs in the other districts from which we have already received requests for new schools.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,

Dear Sir:

The Department is in receipt of a report from L/Cpl. C. Calcrat of the R.C.M.P. in which he states that he visited the Berens River Reserve on January 22. With reference to the Little Grand Rapids U.C. School he writes as follows:

"Thirty children were present at this school although the register recorded fifty-two at times. Twenty-two or three of the children present are Indians, the balance are whites attending from around the settlement. I was also informed that there is some discussion regarding the location of the new school. The band, chief and Councillors desire the school be built on the reserve at the old location. The Missionaries I understand wish it be built by the Mission which is entirely off the reserve and two or three miles from the present school."

Is the Department to infer from the above report that the maximum number of Indian children who will attend this school will be 22 or 23? As you realize we have no responsibility for the education of the white children and in view of reduced appropriation it is impossible to consider providing school accommodation for other than Indian children. A full report on this phase of the school activities at Little Grand Rapids is required.

In connection with the latter part of the officer's report I may say that when the new school is erected the Department must insist on its being built on the Reserve. We are not permitted to erect Indian

Mr. E. McPherson,
Indian Agent,
Selkirk, Man.
day schools off a Reserve. Please let me have your recommendation regarding the location of the new school.

The Department understands from the information contained in your letter of August 1, 1939, that no action has been taken toward the erection of this school. The materials were purchased and paid as requested by your voucher No. 1081/39 of November 21. In view of present conditions and the dissolution of the House I am not in a position at the present time to state what funds, if any, will be available during the fiscal year 1940-41 for the erection of this building. Consequently it is necessary for you to make immediate arrangements to carefully store the material that has been supplied in order that it may be kept intact until it can be used. Please let me know immediately what action you have taken in this regard.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Re: U.C. Indian Day School to be Built at Little Grand Rapids.

Dear Sir:-

I wish to be advised by the Department if it would be satisfactory to have the new school built on the Church property, as this is the best location for it. I looked the ground over last Summer while paying Treaty and I feel satisfied that the site on the Church property would be by far the best. Would we have to get permission from the Church to have the school built on this property and would this arrangement be satisfactory?

One of my reasons for wishing this, is that the teacher's residence is located on the Church ground, and, as the lumber will have to be stored until Spring, it would be more satisfactory to store it where there would be someone to look after it. There is a warehouse on this property where the lumber and cement could be stored until the school is built.

As the Patricia Transportation Company will be starting to haul this material shortly, I wish you would please advise what arrangements you wish me to make.

Very truly yours,

E. McPherson,

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 9th instant with reference to the proposed site of the Little Grand Rapids R.C. Indian Day School.

In this connection I would refer you to the fourth paragraph of my letter of the 14th instant in which it was pointed out that the Department considered that this school should be erected on the Reserve. We made this decision in order that the school would be located at the closest point to the persons it is intended to serve.

From L/Cpl. Calcraf's report it appears that the Mission property is two or three miles from the school and besides it is practically impossible to obtain permission to erect Indian day schools on other than Government property.

From the information contained in my letter of the 14th ultimo you will realize that it is extremely doubtful when funds will be available for the erection of the new building and consequently I consider that the lumber and other materials should be stored in the warehouse on the Church property where it can receive proper supervision. It may involve a slight expenditure to have it transported from this point to the location of the school on the Reserve but at the same time it will no doubt result in none of the materials being stolen.

Yours truly,

Mr. E. McPherson,

Realizing that it is incumbent for me at this time to write you re the choosing of a site for our new school here I trust that you will understand that my sole motive is that the persons concerned are in possession of the most important factors relating to their decision.

In the last mail I received a letter from my predecessor here. He came here in 1927; he built this Mission and left here to go to Berens River in 1936; I shall quote what he has to say regarding the site of our new school: "As to your school, my advice to you is to have all your side included in the Reserve; this was favorably looked on before, and they really need that piece of ground; whatever you do not build the school on the other side; you will see this spring that all the children will be on your side and you will have to take all the children across the lake to school, or have none at school; and that is a big problem for any teacher."

Last September and October I had to take and bring their children to school; this side of the lake is the busy side; both stores are here; the Grand Rapids here and just beyond the rapids lies Lake Pekangecum; their fishing grounds during the open water months they are all camped on this side; there is nobody on the side where the school now is; during these months:

The best land by far is on this side; several times the Band has tried to get this side incorporated in the Reserve; last winter the H.B.C.O. Manager met the Indians at a Band Meeting and I acted as chairman; when he reminded them that it was still not too late to have the Reserve made larger by adding the land on this side which would make it better for all concerned; the old Chief spoke up and said: "Oh! I don't want to go now; who is going to build me a house over there?" That gives you an idea of how much interest he had in two of his children who live on that side care about the welfare of the children and the people as a whole. The other councillor has already moved over here years ago and quite a bunch of the industrious ones of the band; they have built on this side and want the school here; at that meeting we saw that the issue was not with them as to what was best for the people but rather a jealous rivalry between the ones who are located here and the less active ones who stay on the Reserve;" As the land over there is very rocky it is hard to have a garden of any size;

The best solution as I see it is to have the grounds between the mission and the rapids added to the Reserve; the point where our Mission Buildings are was marked by cutting a line through the bush from water to water under the directions of Mr. Schultze my predecessor; that was cut some years ago; you can still see the line and the Indians all recognize it as such; I know the line well as I was one of the two men who cut it; the other man Mr. Kirkness used to be our Missionary at Pekangecum but died some years ago; have the Reserve line run from that line to the Rapids; there is a trader near the Rapids; then across the Rapids is the H.B.C.O.; both of these parties favor this idea; the Trader would I expect wish to have his piece of ground left out of the Reserve; the H.B.C.O. land would in no way be affected;

The future of this place is without doubt on this side; more and more of the Indians express their desire to be over here; the R.C. Mission is in a different position on the Reserve; they are situated at the western end where there is considerable good ground; they would be disinterested as to the site of our school; indeed their present teacher sees the wisdom of our school site being here.

Yours truly,

A.D. Scott

Ottawa, May 7, 1940.

Dear Mr. Street:

I have hesitated to reply to your letter of April 6 until now, not knowing what comment to make in respect to the proposal submitted by you with respect to the site for an Indian day school at Little Grand Rapids.

The funds for the construction of this school were secured prior to the outbreak of the war. We find ourselves at this date with lumber, building material, etc., at Little Grand Rapids but without the money necessary to proceed with the construction.

If, however, it is your opinion that the Indian reserve should be extended to include an area suitable as a site, I am afraid that there is little hope of constructing a school at any time in the immediate future. The extension of an Indian reserve would from the outset involve negotiations with the Provincial Government and the transfer of provincial lands to the Crown in the right of the Dominion. I am not sufficiently optimistic to believe that these negotiations can be undertaken and carried through without a great deal of delay and lengthy correspondence and explanations. It is exceedingly difficult, if not impossible, for the Department to erect an Indian day school other than on property within the boundaries of an Indian reserve.

I am today communicating with Indian Agent McPherson, asking him to undertake a complete survey of conditions at Little Grand Rapids, probably at the time of treaty payments.

Yours sincerely,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare and Training.

Ottawa, May 7, 1940.

Dear Sir:

I am enclosing herewith, for your information, copy of letter received by the Department from Reverend C. D. Street, Indian day school teacher, Little Grand Rapids, Manitoba, and copy of my reply thereto.

It is exceedingly difficult to decide what action, if any, should be taken at Little Grand Rapids, in view of the limited funds at our disposal and the dispute that seems to have arisen in respect to the school site. It is not the policy of the Government, as you are no doubt aware, to establish Indian schools outside the boundaries of Indian reserves.

Would it be possible for you to make a thorough survey of conditions at Little Grand Rapids, probably at the time treaty payments are made? Immediately following that survey, you should be in a position to make certain very definite recommendations to the Department. I can give you no assurance at this date that funds will be available for the construction of the school this year. The suggestion has been made that the lumber already shipped in might be utilized for the repair of both buildings, that is the R. C. school and the United Church school, as representations have been made to us for the establishment of a Roman Catholic school at this point, and that the Indians might be persuaded to undertake the repair work without cost to the Department. However, insomuch as we have promised the United Church to establish a school at this point, representatives of the Church would have to concur in the new arrangement if you considered such an arrangement practicable. I have little on file to indicate the condition of the present buildings. They may have reached a stage where their repair would simply be a waste of money. I should like you, also, to discuss this matter with Inspector Hamilton. If you consider the reserve ought to be extended, it might be advisable for Inspector Hamilton to discuss this extension with the Lands Department of the Provincial Government. The transfer of land, of course, is a matter that comes wholly within the jurisdiction of the Reserves and Trusts Division and any recommendations you and Inspector Hamilton make with respect to the transfer would have to be taken up with the Superintendent of that Division.

You might acknowledge receipt of this letter and let me know when you are likely to visit the Little Grand Rapids district.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir:—

In reply to your letter of July 3rd, 1940, File 125-12-5, relative to the site and building of the U.C. Indian Day School at Little Grand Rapids, I am enclosing herewith a map of the Reserve area, showing the present location of the U.C. Indian Day School.

While making Annuity Payments at Little Grand Rapids this year the question was brought up by the Chief as to where the new school was going to be built. The Chief stated that they wished the school to be built on the present site. Some of the Councillors or members of the Band objected to this suggestion. I would recommend that the school be built on the present school site, which is on Reserve land.

The lumber and cement has been stored in three separate buildings and they are all under lock and key. This material is all stored on the Church property which is situated on the opposite side of the River from the school. The River at this point is approximately half a mile wide. The cement is the only material that will deteriorate if left for another year. We have made inquiries from Contractors as to regarding the cement and they inform us that it will be of practically no use if it is not used this Summer. I would like to make the suggestion that if the Department does not have the money to build this school this Summer, that this cement be given to the Indians for chinking their homes. In this way the cement would not be wasted. However, if the Department decides to build this school this year, I would recommend that it be built on the old site on Reserve land.

Very truly yours,

E. McPherson,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

I wish to refer you to your letter of August 27th, File 125-12-5, relative to repairs to the U.C. and R.C. Indian Day Schools at Little Grand Rapids.

In this connection I wish to advise that I wrote Mr. Bellavance of the R.C. School and Mr. C.D. Street of the U.C. School, requesting them to advise in writing if these two schools could not be put in good condition for Winter use by both schools using some of the materials shipped for the new U.C. School. We have now received replies from both teachers stating that they could repair their schools free of all charges for labour. We have advised them to proceed with the repairs as outlined above.

I feel satisfied that as far as Mr. Bellavance of the R.C. school is concerned, he is very well pleased to be able to get the material, which does not amount to very much, to repair his school. He also informed me that he would do the work himself, free of any charge. On behalf of the Department I wrote him a letter thanking him for his co-operation in this matter.

Mr. Street informed me that he would have the cost of labour for repairing his school done free of any charge. I also wrote a letter thanking him for assisting us in this matter.

I feel satisfied that the school question at Little Grand Rapids is arranged satisfactorily for a few years at least, especially in the case of the R.C. School.

Very truly yours,

E. McPherson,
Indian Agent.

We, the undersigned, loyal subjects of their Majesties—King George and Queen Elizabeth, do under our Treaty Obligations and rights most humbly beseech your government to give its cognizance to the following:
That whereas materials for our new school have been lying here for over a year now; some of it, namely, the cement, deteriorating quickly; all of it losing its qualities more or less;

That whereas the United Church Mission has been established for 68 years among us and serves three-fourths of our people;

Selkirk, Man., March 14, 1941.

Dear Sir:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of March 10th, File 125-12-5, relative to repairs made to the R.C. and U.C. schools at Little Grand Rapids.

I am very much surprised at the contents of the letter received at the Department from Mr. Street, I know that Mr. Street wrote the letter as I had been informed that he was making out a letter for the Indians. I wish to state that Mr. Street and Mr. Bellavance advised me last Fall that if they were able to secure a certain amount of materials that they would be able to put both of their schools in suitable condition for use. I received a letter late last Fall giving me the enclosed list of materials used in repairing both schools. To show you the difference in the two men, Mr. Bellavance wrote me and advised that his school was now in first class condition and thanked the Department for the materials used in making the repairs. He further advised that his school was now in good condition for several years use. Mr. Bellavance's school was in far worse condition than the U.C. school. Mr. Street, on the other hand, appears to have taken the stand that he does not wish to assist the Department by repairing his school to the extent that Mr. Bellavance has done. According to Mr. Street's letter, as Far as I considered that the question was settled but owing to the Hudson's Bay Company going to build at Little Grand Rapids this year, he has decided the school should be built now. I believe that this matter would not have come at all at this time if the Hudson's Bay had not decided to build this year.

I note that he states that the materials are improperly stored. I wish to advise that at Treaty time last Summer this lumber was all under cover and well stored. I am sorry to say that Mr. Street has always been more or less a source of trouble to our Department, as he has always been a great letter writer and in urging the Indians to try and use their influence with the Department regarding supplies, etc., on Reserves where he has been Mississauga. Of course I fully understand that, owing to the material being there on the Reserve, it is putting the Department in a bad position. However, if the Department decides to build this Summer, there will have to be extra material shipped in, which would cost the Department a considerable sum. I consider that the Indians would be perfectly willing to leave matters as they are, as long as the War is going on, if Mr. Street would leave them alone.

R. A. Hoey, Esq.,

Ottawa, March 18, 1941.

Dear Mr. Street:

The Department is in receipt of a petition, dated Grand Rapids, Man., March 3, 1941, signed by the Chief and three councillors of the Little Grand Rapids Band of Indians. It is noted that in this petition the Indians ask for the utilization of the material now on hand for the construction of an Indian day school at Little Grand Rapids.

In this connection may I refer to a letter received from Indian Agent McPherson, dated Selkirk, Man., September 19, 1940. In this letter Mr. McPherson, commenting on conditions at Little Grand Rapids, states:

"I wish to advise that I wrote Mr. Bellavance of the R. C. school and Mr. C. D. Street of the U. C. school, requesting them to advise in writing if these two schools could not be put in good condition for winter use by both schools using some of the materials shipped in for the new United Church school. We have now received replies from both teachers, stating that they could repair their schools free of all charges for labour, and we have advised them to proceed with the repairs as outlined above".

Mr. McPherson, in a letter dated March 14, 1941, referring to the materials sent in for the construction of a school at Little Grand Rapids, states:

"I wish to advise that at treaty time last summer this lumber was all under cover and well stored".

I may state that no provision whatever has been made in the 1941-42 estimates for the construction of an Indian day or residential school anywhere in the Dominion. Indian residential schools have within the last year or so been destroyed by fire at Carcross, Yukon Territory; Albany, James Bay Agency; and quite recently the newly constructed classrooms of the Alberni United Church Residential School at Alberni, British Columbia. When funds are available for the construction

of Indian -

Mr. C. D. Street,
Teacher,
United Church Indian Day School,
Little Grand Rapids, Manitoba.
of Indian schools, these afore-mentioned schools will necessarily have the first claim on our appropriation. In the meantime, it should be pointed out that it is exceedingly difficult for the Dominion Government to secure funds from Parliament for the erection of the buildings necessary to maintain our regular services. A number of the provinces have placed at the disposal of the Dominion Government, without cost, institutions ordinarily used for the care of the sick and the education of their citizens. Outstanding in this respect is the action of the province of Ontario which placed at the disposal of the Dominion the seven million dollar building at Peterborough, Ont. It is my further statement also that the Manitoba Government has placed at the disposal of the Dominion the Manitoba School for the Deaf, Tuxedo, Man. It should be stated also that the Public Works Department of the Federal Government has abandoned a number of post offices, for the construction of which contracts had been completed.

The only suggestion, therefore, that I can make in the case of the school at Little Grand Rapids is that the materials now on hand be used to the best possible advantage for the repair of the existing building. If the Indians are interested in the education of their children, they might be persuaded to undertake this work in the interests of the young and as a patriotic duty. They should be reminded that we are living in the most critical period in Canadian history, when the country is actually fighting for its existence. It is gratifying to learn, from the last paragraph of the petition, that the Indians do not wish to ask for anything that would interfere with the nation's war effort. In view of this declaration, I feel confident that by the exercise of your influence you can persuade the Indians to repair and reconstruct the present building to such an extent that it will provide school accommodation for the pupils in attendance until times become somewhat normal.

Yours very truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare and Training.

Dear Mr. Hoeg:

Have received your letter of March 18th re Indian petition concerning erection of school here.

Referring to Agent's letter to you Sept. 19th, 1940, I wish to state that I did repair our old building. However, with an old log, plastered, building, there is a limit to which such repairs are wisely carried out. For instance the floor is terrible, but the condition of the roof does not warrant a new floor. There is no ceiling, yet the cross beams are so low that a new ceiling is out of the question. And may I might go on from here. I worked.
15 days and in that time made the old place as habitable as I could; very much better than it was before.

And then concerning the Agent letter dated March 8th, 1941. Again the agent is correct. However, the only stockhouses are being used for this, which makes it inconvenient for the Mission. The roofs of these 3 storied houses are all in need of repair.

In regard to your last paragraph may I say that in my opinion little saving of any considerable quantity of materials or labor to replace old building is a matter of question. If put the old place in as good condition as I could without as before stated carrying out an unnecessary use of valuable materials on an old delapidated place.

Again our people are all away now. There
will return next month. School will reopen on June 1st. All Indians who can will get work on H.B.C. construction work here. Those who cannot will fight on the river if fighting can be gotten. And those not able to get work will probably leave to hunt and fish where game is plentiful.

It has indeed a pity that a way could not be found of building a new school this summer. To see 65 sacks of cement harden like a rock and be thrown away, a waste of around $300, while the H.B.C. is building 2 or 3 new buildings a stone's throw away is hard to be understood, by the Indians.

When Mr. Graham, the H.B.C. travelling inspector was here he told the Indians and me that he would be very glad to do all
he could to help build our school. The Indians themselves would be quick to help if they were given enough to exist on while working—say $1.60 a day.

I trust I have explained everything to you also, hoping that a way will be found to build school this summer before cement is useless.

Thanking you very much

Yours truly,

C.S. [Signature]
Ottawa, April 15, 1941.

Dear Mr. Street:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the first instant and to thank you for the information contained therein.

No provision whatever has been made in the estimates now before Parliament for the construction of Indian day or residential schools anywhere in the Dominion. In view of this decision, it will not be possible to seriously consider the construction of the Indian day school in which you are interested at Little Grand Rapids.

I was sorry to learn that the cement on hand had deteriorated somewhat. It was my hope that storage facilities could be provided at Little Grand Rapids that would have kept this cement in good condition. However, if it has deteriorated, there is little that can be done about the matter. In view of the critical period in which we find ourselves and the desire on the part of Canadians everywhere to conserve public funds, would it be possible to have the Indians at Little Grand Rapids undertake more extensive repairs to the school than appear to have been undertaken at this time? I make this suggestion with the feeling that it may be several years before money is available to undertake the construction of public buildings anywhere, other than buildings urgently needed for war purposes.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare and Training.

Mr. C. D. Street,
Teacher, U. C. Indian Day School,
Little Grand Rapids, Manitoba.

Dear Dr. Cormie:

On the eighth of this month Mr. Talbot and Mr. Cowper of the H.B.C.O. visited here in connection with the building of their new unit here which is to be adjoining our Church site.

I took up with them the predicament we are in concerning the erection of our new school here. They were at once interested as to whether they might be of assistance to us. It was thought by them that their carpenters could possibly be persuaded to supervise the work on our school if the Indians were to do the work. Then the question of rationing was taken up and they expressed themselves as willing to do their share and hoped that some arrangement might be made whereby the Govt. and the H.B.C. and Church find a solution.

Would you please do what you can in order that our school be built and so make use of all these valuable materials especially the cement.

Re: Little Grand Rapids Indian Day School.

Dear Doctor Dorey:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 4th instant and also copy of a letter received by Dr. Cornie from Mr. C. D. Street, teacher at the above noted school, enclosed therewith.

I should state that an appropriation for the erection of an Indian day school at Little Grand Rapids was included in the 1939 estimates. However, certain delays occurred and we found it impossible to proceed with the construction of the school during the year 1940, for the simple reason that no funds for this purpose were available, the 1939 funds having lapsed.

The delays I have in mind were the delays in securing the material and shipping it to Grand Rapids and a dispute in respect to the exact site. It was finally decided that a portion of the building material sent in should be used for the repair of the school, and I was informed that partial repairs were undertaken. It has not been found possible to include a sum in the estimates of this year for the construction of an Indian day or residential school anywhere in the Dominion. The Government has simply suspended the construction of all buildings other than those necessary for the war effort. I notice that one or two post offices that were already started have been abandoned.

I am however today communicating with Mr. Street, and if he can persuade the Indians to undertake this task, in return for a ration allowance, the Department would be prepared to supply these Indians with rations during the period of construction. I note with interest that the Hudson's Bay Company would be prepared to have their carpenters supervise this work. It is this offer on the part of the H. B. C. that prompts me to make the offer of rations on behalf of the Department.

Yours very truly,

R A Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare and Training.

Selkirk, Man., July 18, 1941.

AIR MAIL

Dear Sir:

Re: Proposed U.C. Indian Day School, Little Grand Rapids.

Regarding your letter of July 4th, File 125-12-5, I wish to advise that this letter was received here on July 5th and I immediately wrote Mr. Street, instructing him that the Department would allow $350.00 for rations for Indian labour building the school. I informed him that there would be no further material supplied and that the school would have to be built on Reserve property.

I note in the copy of your letter to Mr. Street dated June 12th that he must have informed you that the Company would supervise the work of building the school. I informed Street that there would be no wages paid for a carpenter. On July 11th I received a letter from Mr. Street in which he requested me to interview Mr. Talbot as Mr. Street stated in this letter that if the Department paid the ration bill, the Hudson's Bay Company would supply a carpenter. I could not understand why the Company would supply a carpenter at no cost to us, so on July 14th I interviewed Mr. Talbot and he told me that they certainly would not supply a carpenter and pay his wages.

While making Treaty payments at Little Grand Rapids yesterday, this question was brought up and Mr. Street now states that the carpenters will do the work but their labour alone will cost $350.00 while an extra $300.00 is required for Indian labour moving supplies across the River to the site of the school and for labour working on the school. Street wishes to know by Monday, July 21st if the Department will supply this extra money, as the carpenter and his men will be leaving Little Grand Rapids on Tuesday if nothing is to be done regarding the school.

Please advise by wire what action you are taking.

Very truly yours,

E. McPherson,

Mr. McPherson wrote the teacher at Grand Rapids, Mr. Dueck, on December 16th, 1943, informing him that he should hold school on the reserve and pointed out that there was lumber on hand to repair the school and make it comfortable.

This letter was sent to Dr. Cormie by Mr. Dueck. Dr. Cormie points out that the old classroom is not in shape to be used and in his opinion was not worth repairing. The children are being taught in the Church and according to Dr. Cormie this has been the case for the past year or two. During the conversation Dr. Cormie stated the Indians were satisfied with the arrangement.

I would like the Department's approval to continue the present arrangement for this term at least. At treaty time this year the old school can be inspected by the Agent and some recommendation made then regarding what should be done to provide suitable classroom accommodation.

A.G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies for Manitoba.
Ottawa,
January 28, 1944.

Mr. A.G. Hamilton, Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Winnipeg, Man.

I have your letter of the 24th instant,
with reference to the Little Grand Rapids Indian
Day School. In 1941 we supplied materials to
repair this school. We were requested by Indian
Agent McPherson to forward $350.00 for labour.
This was done, but in a letter dated July 18, 1941,
he stated that $650.00 would be required and this
extra amount was not available at that time.
Presumably the materials that we supplied in 1941
are still stored at the school, although I believe
some of the material was used in repairing another
school, due to the fact that Mr. Street, who was in
charge of the Little Grand Rapids U.C. School at
that time, did not carry out the repairs which he
previously stated he could do.

In view of the information contained
in the second and third paragraphs of your letter,
I think the present arrangement should continue
until Treaty time, when the school should be
inspected by the Agent and a definite recommendation
forwarded regarding suitable classroom accommodation
at this point.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Ottawa, January 31, 1945.

Mr. E. McPherson, Indian Agent, Selkirk, Manitoba.

In a letter dated January 24, 1944, Mr. A.G. Hamilton, Inspector of Indian Agencies, wrote to the Department with reference to the Little Grand Rapids United Church School. I presume he wrote to you at the same time, as the recommendation in his letter was that the arrangement of holding school in the church should continue until treaty time. We do not appear to have received any further communication in regard to conditions at the Little Grand Rapids United Church School. However, I may say that recently we received a complaint to the effect that the lumber and other materials, which we understood were well stored (see your letter of March 14, 1941), are not being properly looked after. We understand that some of the material was used in 1941 for repairing the Little Grand Rapids R.C. School and also a small quantity in repairing the Little Grand Rapids U.C. School.

Did you have an opportunity of inspecting this material at treaty time in 1944? If not, have you any information regarding where this material is stored and the condition in which it is kept? An early reply will be appreciated.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

E. McPherson, Esq., Indian Agent Selkirk, Man.

As per instructions I visited the R.C. and U.C. Day Schools while at Little Grand Rapids Reserve for Annuity payments this year.

I am attaching map of this area showing the approximate positions of our two schools the H.B.Co and the Missions. You will not there is no Reserve land on the north side of Family Lake near the H.B.Co and the U.C.Mission. The Teacher lives in the U.C.Mission and has to cross approximately one mile of water to the school every day. In the spring and late fall this crossing is not possible owing to the ice conditions. From information gathered I understand for two thirds of the school term the families of the U.C. pupils move from the reserve across near the H.B.Co and during this period the Teacher has been transporting them back and forth by canoe to school but of late has been holding classes in the Mission House. The Indians seem to favor a new school being built near the Mission on the north side of the Lake. This would not be on Reserve property. The Manager of the H.B.Post states that the Company does not own the land where their buildings are and doubts if the Church owns the land where the Mission buildings are. Except for the fact that it would not be on the Reserve, the logical site would appear to be on the north side of the lake.

The present U.C.School is a log building 24 x 24. It is in very poor repair and too small for the number of children that should attend. There are nineteen on the roll and should be approximately thirty. The attendance will undoubtedly increase owing to the regulations governing the family allowances. There are no outside toilets at this school and material should be included for these when making up a bill of material for a new school. I would suggest a lean-to kitchen on the school for preparation of the mid-day meals.

The R.C. School is a log building 20 x 16 in very poor repair and too small. There should be approximately thirty-five children on the roll at this school. Some of the new lumber for the U.C.School was used here for a ceiling and minor interior repairs to make the building warm enough for winter use. I understand that the R.C. pupils are on the reserve during most of the school term so the present site would be satisfactory for a new school.
Owing to the fact that the U.C.School can not be used now and the condition and size of the R.C.School I would recommend that two new schools be built here as soon as circumstances will permit.

The material already shipped for the U.C.School is well protected from weather. It is stored in three small log buildings belonging to the U.C.Mission. It was difficult to get an exact check of all this material without taking it outside I made as careful a check as possible of all material on hand and have enclosed a list of same.

These schools closed for summer vacation June 30th and will re-open Sept 1st.

Ottawa, March 27, 1946.

Mr. E. McPherson, Indian Agent,
Selkirk, Manitoba.

With reference to your letter of the 19th instant, it has been decided to pay voucher No. 757. However, you should point out to all teachers that they must not make purchases for which they expect the Department to pay, until the requisite authority has been received.

We have no intention at the present time of decreasing the amount that we have previously allowed yearly for midday meal purposes. However, in view of the payment of family allowances, it is felt that if the money is properly expended by the parents, the children should be better fed and clothed and consequently we do not see the necessity for increasing the amount for midday meal purposes.

Philip Phelan,

Extract from Acting Indian Agent F. M. Hughes' report on a trip to the Little Grand Rapids Reserve, Clandeboye Agency, February 18th and 19th, 1947.

Original report, dated Feb. 21st, on file 64-125.

"If the Department intends building a new U. C. school there I should be advised soon so that I can have an inventory taken of the material on the site and any more required can go in before break-up".

F. M. Hughes,
Acting Indian Agent.
Ottawa, March 1st, 1947.

Mr. F.M. Hughes, Acting Indian Agent,
Selkirk, Manitoba.

We are in receipt of your report of your visit to the Little Grand Rapids Reserve and in reply I wish to advise you that funds are being provided in the appropriation for the fiscal year 1947-48 for the erection of a new U.C. school on the Little Grand Rapids Reserve.

Please have an inventory taken of the material on the site and let me have detailed information regarding the additional material that you consider is required.

We propose to build a combined school and teachers' residence. Does this meet with your approval?

Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

c/o to Inspector Hamilton.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept of Mines & Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

I have received a copy of an account from the T. Eaton Co. Ltd. for material forwarded to our Little Grand Rapids U.C. School in March, 1945. This material was purchased on Department Order No. 2502 and our Voucher No. 810 - $45.25 went forward for payment March 30/46. The Company state they have not yet received payment of this account.

F. M. Hughes,
Acting Indian Agent
Ottawa, March 18th, 1947.

Mr. F.M. Hughes, Acting Indian Agent,
Selkirk, Manitoba.

With reference to your letter of the 5th instant regarding T. Eaton Company account, our records show that cheque 58873 for $45.25 was issued and sent to the T. Eaton Company on April 13th, 1946.

Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept of Mines & Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

Your letter 125-12-5 (WT 1) of March 1/47 was received here March 7/47 and I immediately forwarded a message to the Teacher to have a complete inventory taken of the material on the Little Grand School site. A copy of this inventory is enclosed. I have a copy of an inventory taken by myself two years ago but with no one in charge of the present school for some months thought it advisable to have another taken.

I am of the opinion that a combined school and residence on this reserve would be very satisfactory, however, having no plans of the building you propose to erect I cannot give an estimate of balance of material required.

F. M. Hughes,
Acting Indian Agent

Your letter of November 24, concerning sawmill for the Poplar River Indian Reserve, has been brought to my attention. While it is our intention to eventually build a school at Poplar River, we were only able to include one school for your agency in our estimates. This school will be at Little Grand Rapids for the United Church. We already have some lumber at the site of this school (a search of your files will reveal the exact quantities).

The question is: Would it be feasible to haul lumber across the lake from Poplar River to Little Grand Rapids, if your mill was set up there? We could provide you with the bill of materials required for the construction of our standard one-room Indian day school and teacher's residence. You could then delete the materials already on hand plus the materials which you could provide from your sawmill. This would then leave a list of materials which could be requisitioned for from outside. However, as pointed out above, a lot depends upon the practicability of the suggestion that materials be transported from your proposed sawmill across the lake to Little Grand Rapids.

We would appreciate an early answer to the above proposal.

It is desired to submit the following observations for your consideration relating to our Little Grand Rapids situation.

Indian housing on this Reserve is in a deplorable state. Special effort was put forth to obtain improvement with result we have five blocks erected and logs out for five more. It was my intention to use major portion of our Agency balance in allotment 10 and 13, vote 515, to ship windows and assorted lumber by Tractor Train this winter for housing assistance next spring. If we miss this shipment, we can do nothing to aid housing at Little Grand Rapids until 1949.

That order to North American Lumber Company, Winnipeg, for one room Pre-Fabricated Day School be enlarged to include Teachers Residence attached to school, per plan submitted by this Company for your consideration last fall. The cost would not exceed $2,000.00 extra for pre-fabricated joint residence and school. In having school and residence in one unit, we save on excavation costs, one basement wall and one house wall,

If this were acceptable, then we could use Bill of material on hand at Little Grand Rapids (now intended for Teachers Residence) to assist regarding housing improvements.
