GENERAL:

(See Quotation.)

1. MATERIALS TO BE USED IN BASEMENT.

Sufficient basement form material will be supplied for a full basement and will be billed as an addition to the basic price.

A 5-ply 2x10 laminated beam with sufficient wedges to shim concrete posts for which we supply form material - thirteen basement window assemblies and one steel coal chute to be installed as shown on plans; and basement partition material complete with door assemblies shall be supplied for heating and manual training room. Material to form door openings through concrete walls is supplied (K.D.), and is to be removed after concrete is poured prior to installation of door assemblies. Sufficient 2x8 material with anchor bolts is supplied to be laid on top of concrete walls set down in the concrete flush with the outside edge of wall. Basement stair assembly landing platform and finished stair to floor level will be supplied completely assembled. Newells hand rails and baluster stock, etc. is supplied in bundle form.

The main stair from landing to floor level is constructed of 2x10 clear fir housed out to receive risers and tread which are glued and wedged into place. Risers are of 1x8 clear fir K.D. and treads are of K.D. Oak.

2. FLOOR SECTIONS.

Prefabricated floor sections are constructed of 2x8 joists at 16" centres. Sub-flooring is 1" shiplap applied diagonally with all joints cut over joists. Finish flooring is 13/16"x1 3/4" #2 Maple is supplied for application at the site in all rooms except kitchen. Finish flooring in kitchen consists of 5/16" Plywood which is applied over sub-flooring at the site as a base for "A" gauge linoleum, which is supplied along with cement to be applied at the site. Insulation has been left out of floors because we do not recommend insulation with a full basement.
Outside walls are prefabricated in panels of 2x4 studding spaced at 16" centres with double top and double bottom plate. The double bottom plate is left off panels and is supplied in lineal footage to be nailed down solidly through sub-floors and joists to the layout of partitions at time of erection forming a solid key. On the 11'6" wall, two rows of 2x4" girths are installed in panels for class room; on 8'3" wall, a solid line of 2x4" girths is installed at 4' height. Outside sheathing is 5/16" exterior grade rough plywood sheathing fastened to the studs with coated nails. Wall sections are insulated in the factory with Full-thick Rock-Wool Batts or Fibre Glass insulation fastened between studding over which is applied one-ply Duplex Scutan vapor seal paper. The interior finish is standard quality 1/4"-3 ply weatherboard plywood. Johns Manville Cedar Grain Shingles and 12# asphalt felt is supplied for application at the site for exterior finish.

Ceilings:

Ceiling panels are supplied for residence portion only; constructed of 2x6 joists on 16" centres; 1x2 strapping on 12" centres across joists; and 1x6 fillers over wall plate to form backing for ceiling mouldings. Vapor Seal paper is applied over strapping over which is laid 1/4" interior grade plywood sheets with minimum joints.

Ceiling for class room is constructed in the following manner at the site after erection of roof trusses. 1x2" strapping is to be laid on 12" centres firmly nailed to the underside of the bottom cords of trusses. Vapor seal paper is then applied over strapping over which is applied 1/4" 4x8 sheets of weatherboard plywood for ceiling finish.

Ceilings for entry is constructed in the following manner:- 2x4 collar ties are to be firmly nailed to rafters 8'3" off floor to the underside of collar ties. Insulation is then applied between collar ties and the sloping portion of rafters over which is laid vapor seal paper and the 1/4" weatherboard inside finish.

Insulation: Sufficient Full-Thick RockWool is supplied to cover entire ceiling area of class-room, residence ceiling and vestibule ceiling.

(Con't.)
6. ROOF SECTIONS:

Roofs for residence portion are constructed in panels; 2x4 rafters on 16" centres; 1x6 ridge board, 2x4 bottom plate which is firmly nailed at time of erection into ceiling joists. Rafters are sheathed over with 1" shiplap applied horizontally on the panels in the factory. 2x4 collar ties are supplied for application at the site to go at 16" o.c.

Roof over class-room, which we are supplying, has trusses which are to be placed at 2' centres and is constructed as follows: 2x6 top cords, 2x4 bottom cords, 2x4 braces which are securely fastened with gusset plates of 5/16" exterior plywood and nailed with coated nails on both sides of trusses. Eave sockets are formed with filler blocks which are attached to trusses giving a 12" overhang outside of base of wall. A 2x4 ridge board is supplied which is to be inserted into the opening into truss at time of erection. A single 2x8 filler plate is supplied which is to be firmly nailed over cloak room partition as trusses fall on either side for a good nailing for ceiling strapping. 2x4 filler blocks are supplied to be used as spacers for trusses, at top of outside wall which also form the nailing strip for ceiling strapping. Roof sheathing is supplied for application at the site. 1x6 lateral braces are supplied which are to be firmly nailed at top edge of bottom cord to prevent sway.

Roof over vestibule is constructed the same as roof over residence portion. 210# Asphalt shingles are supplied together with 12# asphalt paper with starter strips and galvanized iron flashing for application at the site.

7. GABLE ENDS:

Gable Ends sections are constructed in a like manner to trusses with 2x4 additional fillers which are applied 5/16" exterior grade rough plywood sheathing the same as outside walls.

8. WINDOWS, DOORS & LOUVRES:

Window frames are factory made with exterior trim applied ready for fitting into openings at time of erection. Windows are 1 3/4" thickness, double glazed S.S. Glass equipped with sash locks, balances, weather stripping and sash lifts. Storm Sash are 1 3/8" thickness, single glazed with S.S. glass,
8. WINDOWS, DOORS & LOUVRES (CON'T.)

equipped with buttons and screws; Half screens for the school building with full screens for all basement windows—1 3/8" thickness black wire mesh—equipped with hooks and eyes for fastening to frames.

Exterior door frames are 2" fir K.D. - 3"x7" x 1 3/4" exterior door is installed in frame in factory completely equipped with hardware in factory. All inside door frames are constructed of 1" stock in which is hung standard quality mono-doors equipped with hardware as shown in plan.

Two triangular louvre and one rectangular louvre with screen wire backing is supplied for installation into the gables at the site for attic ventilation.

9. EXTERIOR AND INTERIOR TRIM.

All inside window and door casings are supplied ready-cut and mitred for easy application at the site. All other inside mouldings are supplied random lengths for application after the building is erected.

Exterior trim consisting of lxlo base and 2 1/4" water table that is installed prior to application of Cedar Grain Siding. 5/4x4 or 5 corner board assemblies are to be installed over two-ply paper on corners. lx12 eave soffits are supplied in random lengths. Barge and facia boards are of lx6 stock. 3/4" Cove is supplied to go over facia at rake of gables. Gable soffits are of lxlo stock.

Interior trim to consist of 1/2 x4 B.N. Base, carpet strip, floor moulding, 3/4" Crown Moulding for ceiling, 3/4" Cove for corners and burlap mould for section joints.

Closet shelving material is supplied cut to lengths for installation at the site. One piece of 18' shelving -5/4x10 clear fir stock which is to be installed under window stool in class room with steel brackets is also supplied.

lx6 Clear Fir random length boards will be supplied together with coat hooks for the cloak room.

Two insulated man holes will also be supplied for accessibility to ceilings of class-room and residence.

(Con't.)
10. **CUPBOARDS:**

Kitchen cupboards are supplied completely built and ready to install—complete with topping material and hardware.

One sink - 16x24x8 Strainer Type - is supplied for installation at the site, and two five-gallon waste pails.

11. **CHIMNEY:**

One 8" flue insulated metal chimney is provided for the furnace which extends through from the main floor to the roof of the building. One 7" insulated metal chimney is supplied for the residence portion of the school which extends from the ceiling of the residence through the roof.

12. **BLACKBOARDS:**

Two - 16' and one 14' composition blackboards including mouldings, and chalk rail and backer strips as specified by Moyer School Supplies is supplied.

13. **HEATING:**

One only 30-R Prairie Pride wood burning stove equivalent to the No. 1024 Gurney Wood furnace is supplied.

14. **PAINT:**

All inside wall surfaces, door and window assemblies, all interior trim and flooring is sprayed with one coat of Timberlox as a primer sealer and water repelent. Sufficient Sherwin-Williams Paint for a 2-coat paint job which is to be applied to all the interior trim which is already sprayed giving a three-coat paint job, is supplied. A three-coat paint job is given all exterior surfaces.

15. No fixtures, teacher's closets, desks of any type are supplied as they have been omitted on our quotations.

PRECIS FOR THE CLERK OF THE PRIVY COUNCIL:

Requesting authority for the provision of a combined one-room Indian day school and teacher's residence on the Little Grand Rapids Reserve, Glandeboye Indian Agency in the Province of Manitoba, for which funds are provided in the 1947-48 estimates.

Two extra copies of Order-in-Council are required.
March 5, 1948.

TO HIS EXCELLENCY

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL,

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT it is immediately necessary, and funds are provided in the 1947-48 estimates, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources, to provide a one-room Indian day school and teacher's residence on the Little Grand Rapids Reserve, Clandoboya Indian Agency in the Province of Manitoba;

THAT it is essential that educational facilities be provided for the Indian children on the Little Grand Rapids Reserve and living quarters for the Indian day school teacher;

THAT Section 36 of the Public Works Act, Chapter 166, R.S.C., 1927, provides, in part as follows:-

"Whenever any works are to be executed under the direction of any Department of the Government the Minister having charge of such Department shall invite tenders by public advertisement for the execution of such works except in cases (a) or pressing emergency in which delay would be injurious to the public interest . . . .";

THAT, due to the very isolated situation of this reserve, there are no builders or contractors in the area nor are outside contractors interested in tenders if invited as aforesaid, as they have all the work they can do in their own localities;

THAT a competent building company, namely the North American Buildings, Limited, Winnipeg, Manitoba, has agreed to undertake the provision of a prefabricated school and teacher's residence immediately on a basis of $6,739.73 F.O.B. Winnipeg, plus freight and erection supervisor's wages, fare and expenses.

THAT it is considered that the provision of this school and attached teacher's residence is a pressing emergency and within the exemption provided in Section 36 above recited and further, it is considered that the work can be more expeditiously and economically executed as suggested herein.

The undersigned, therefore, recommends that authority be granted for the provision of this building as
outlined above, this being the only arrangement possible at the present time and it being essential that this work be undertaken at once and carried to completion in order that the building will be available for use by the time the next school term commences.

Respectfully submitted,

Minister of Mines and Resources.

Ottawa, April 25, 1927.

Very Reverend Sir:

Rev. Father J. Guy, O.M.I., has written to the Department with reference to the request you forwarded from Brother F. Leach, concerning the recognition of the Little Grand Rapids R.C. Indian Day School. I have noted that a satisfactory commencement has been made and I am pleased to state that a salary of $4 per teaching day will be allowed for the activity. As from the first instant Brother Leach should forward day school quarterly returns to the Indian office at Selkirk. In view of the difficulty of communicating with Little Grand Rapids, it might be advisable to have the salary cheques made out to you in trust for Brother Leach. Salary will be paid upon receipt of the returns. I trust that this activity will be one of much usefulness for our Indian wards of the locality. I regret that no funds can be allowed for building activity at this point. Favourable consideration will be given, however, to all requisitions for stationery, books, etc. Please inform the teacher.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Very Rev. J. Magnan, O.M.I.,
340 Provencher Ave.,
St. Boniface, Man.

MEMORANDUM

Representative of the Treasury,

Re School No. 524.

Mr. Boniface Guimond has been transferred from the Bloodwein R. C. Day School to the Little Grand Rapids R. C. Day School with salary at the rate of $80 a teaching month.

He will succeed Antoine Guimond from September 1st, 1936, and the following entry should appear on the September paylist in connection with this school:

524 - Boniface Guimond - c/o Banque Canadienne - $80.00 Nationale,
St. Boniface, Man.

Mr. Guimond's services will be continuous from the above date.
Mr. Philip Phelan  
266 Holmewood Ave.  
OTTAWA, Ont.

My dear Phil:

Reverend Father de Grandpré of Berens River is under the impression that the Department promised to pay Boniface Guimond the sum of $186.50 for freight expenses incurred by him in the summer of 1936. If there is any foundation for this assumption and if the amount has not yet been paid, you will render Father de Grandpré a real service by having a cheque issued at your earliest convenience as Father de Grandpré financed Boniface Guimond all through last summer and he would now like to be paid back.

Boniface Guimond could easily pay him if the Department reimbursed him for his freight expenses. The whole matter could also be more easily adjusted if the cheque, although made in the name of Boniface Guimond, was mailed to Reverend Father de Grandpré at Berens River.

Please accept in advance my sincerest thanks for anything that you may be able to do for Father de Grandpré.

With best wishes to the lady of the house and the children, I am,

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Reverend J. O. Flourde, O.M.I.
Ottawa, June 15th, 1937.

Dear Father Plourde,-

I have your letter of the 8th instant, with reference to the amount owing to Father de Grandpre by Boniface Guimond. Unless we receive an order from Guimond authorizing payment to Father de Grandpre, I regret that present regulations will not permit a cheque being sent to the latter.

As you know, we have to issue each salary cheque in favour of the teacher himself. You will remember my mentioning to you that, at one time in the case of the United Church, we used to issue all salary cheques for day schools under their auspices to the church but, for the last four years, we have had to issue all these cheques to the individuals concerned. In many of the United Church schools, they are up against the same difficulty as Father de Grandpre as they have to issue advances to many teachers.

I still feel that it would be in the best interests of all parties concerned to retire Mr. Boniface Guimond from Indian school work.

As mentioned above, I am sorry I cannot do anything in this matter as I am only too willing to help Father de Grandpre if that were at all possible but present regulations are so strict that I cannot see any way of circumventing them.

Yours sincerely,

Rev. J. O. Plourde, O.M.I.,
619 McDermot Ave.,
Winnipeg, Man.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6239, file 524-3, part 1)
Ottawa,
October 12, 1937.

Dear Father Plourde:

With reference to your letter of October 9th, I would refer you to my letter of June 15th last, a copy of which I enclose.

I have a faint recollection of having received a letter from Father de Grandpre, but am unable to find a copy of my reply. I could not possibly have promised him that we would pay the freight expenses of Mr. Guimond. Expenses of teachers of Indian Day Schools, either for their personal travelling, or for the freight on their household effects, have never been paid by the Department.

The only way that we could make a payment to Father de Grandpre is by securing a Power of Attorney from Mr. Guimond authorizing payment of a part, or the whole, of his salary to Father de Grandpre. I enclose the necessary Power of Attorney form which Mr. Guimond must sign.

I regret that I cannot do anything further in this matter, but you realize that our regulations in this regard are extremely strict.

Yours truly,

Rev. J.O. Plourde, O.M.I.,
619 McDermot Ave.,
Winnipeg, Man.

Sir,

Replying to your letter, No. 125-30-5, dated 15th July re- requisition from Rev. F. Leach, O.M.I., Little Grand Rapids R.C. Indian Day School, for supplies for mid-day meal, I beg to enclose copy of requisition, with the amount of supplies which I would recommend, noted in red ink. The original quantities asked for, I have reduced to what I consider should be sufficient for the school attendance.

Permit me to express my views on this subject. I am strongly in favor of giving the Indian children the best education possible, even giving the pupils a mid-day meal, if that will help to increase the attendance, but when that meal is given as an excuse for keeping the men at home and away from their trap lines in winter, I think it is time to call a halt. If these conditions are allowed to go on, it is impossible to foresee what problems the Department will be up against, in the way of supplying more destitute rations and supplies. At some of the reserves I visited this summer hardly any of the men went away trapping last winter; the reason given was that they wanted the children to attend school. At the Bloodvein Reserve, only four families went to the bush. When I paid there in June, I found that most of their treaty money had been taken up at the stores.

You will notice that I have struck out the 50 lbs. of sugar in the requisition, as this is hardly necessary along with a case of sweetened condensed milk.

I have received a letter from Mr. Leach, offering, if his requisition is approved of, to freight in the supplies to Little Grand Rapids for 5½c per lb. The usual rate is 7½c per lb.

I regret the delay in answering your letter and would greatly appreciate an early reply, so that these supplies can be forwarded at once.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs,
Indian Agent,
Ottawa.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 31st ultimo, with reference to supplies for the midday lunch at the Little Grand Rapids R.C. Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to say it is only intended that children should be given either hot soup or a hot drink and biscuit to supplement whatever food they bring to school for their midday meal. The teachers of all the day schools in your Agency should be cautioned not to pauperize the Indians by serving a full meal. By following out the wishes of the Department in this regard the amount of supplies required would be considerably reduced.

I note from your letter that you recommend the supplying of 100 Lbs. beans, 50 Lbs. rice, 25 Lbs. cocoa and 1 case condensed milk. You may secure these, and have them forwarded as you suggest. An order is being placed with the Canada Biscuit Co., Winnipeg, for 25 boxes biscuits. Please communicate with this firm at once giving them full shipping directions.

You may also purchase 1 axe, 2 water pails, 6 Yds. towelling, 2 combs, 2 basins, 2 brooms and 6 Lbs. yarn.

Dear Sir:

Following is an extract from the December quarter return of the teacher of the Little Grand Rapids R. C. Indian Day School:

"I have very good children; they are very good in class, only they are half-starving, at least some of them. I wish they would get more beans, rice and biscuits next year.

"I cannot afford to feed them out of my pocket. I am in debt over all my wages already this year; everything is so dear here at Little Grand Rapids.

"I want to thank you again for the school materials you sent this year.

"If I would get help to have my stuff freighted up here every year, I believe I would be able to do more good to my starving pupil every winter."

The Department cannot understand what the teacher means in the first paragraph of his letter. Authority to purchase supplies for midday meal purposes was given in official letter of June 13th, last, and, according to accounts received, the supplies authorized were sent to the school. I would appreciate hearing from you regarding the teacher's statements.

Dear Sir:

With further reference to your letter No. 125-30-5 of March 13th, we have today received a report concerning conditions at the R.C. Indian Day School at Little Grand Rapids.

It would appear that the work at this school is an absolute joke. I am now informed on reliable authority that the school is often closed for a week at a time, other times there are only four and five children attending.

There is no reason why his pupils should know anything about the pangs of hunger if he allows them to consume the supplies for Midday meal purposes that were sent to them. As for his purchasing supplies for the school, it is simply a joke.

It might be well to investigate the qualifications of this man to teach in any school, where some semblance of progress is required.

Your obedient servant,

Andrew Irwin,

OTTAWA.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of a letter from Reverend Father Lamontagne, Provincial of the Oblate Order in Manitoba, in which he calls my attention to the plight of the Indians of Berens River, Blood Vein and Little Grand Rapids. There is almost no hunting and very little fishing and the Indians are in the most destitute condition.

May I hope that you will ask your agent or your inspector to pay a visit to these reserves as soon as possible and, if conditions are found to be as stated, that you will send relief to these poor Indians.

Mr Boniface Guimont, the day school teacher at Little Grand Rapids, writes the following about the condition of the Indians in a letter which I have just received: "I received only twelve boxes of biscuits last fall which were exhausted a long time ago, considering the amount of pupils I had. Moreover half of the biscuits were spoiled. Now the people are starving and it is not unusual to see the poor kids coming to school with empty stomachs. A person should see this to realize it, "It's Terrible". Would you not put in a good word for them and have the Department instruct the agent to send them help; little though it may be it will be a help before they can go out to catch muskrats. Right now there is no fur, and the store-keepers can't manage to feed them".

I have no doubt that if these conditions really exist, you will want to correct them immediately.

Thanking you in anticipation, I remain,

yours very truly,

[Signature]

Dear Sir:

The Department has received a complaint originating from the Provincial of the Oblate Order in Manitoba in which it is stated that Mr. Boniface Guimont, the day school teacher at Little Grand Rapids, complains of the receipt last Fall of only twelve boxes of biscuits, one half of which were spoiled. I wish to point out in the first place that six hundred and fifty pounds biscuits were shipped for use at the school of which Mr. Guimont is the teacher, packed in twenty-six boxes and the Department would like to ascertain how it came about that Mr. Guimont only received twelve.

The Department also wishes to know whether you received a previous complaint from Mr. Guimont as to the condition of the biscuits as it is the first indication that the shipment consigned for use at that school was not satisfactory.

Selkirk, Man., March 22nd, 1937.

Dear Sir:

Replying to your letter of the 17th instant relative to school biscuits supplied to the Little Grand Rapids R.C. Indian Day School.

As you are aware the school biscuits last year were greatly reduced from what was estimated for. On reports received from Const. C. Calcraft, R.C.M.P. Berens River detachment, to the effect that the R.C. School at Little Grand Rapids was only opened for teaching at odd times, we concluded, that it was only fair to make a more equitable distribution of the biscuits supplied. This was done Pro Rata, based on attendance at the two schools.

We also notified the Department on March 20th, 1936 regarding conditions at this school, as we had been advised on reliable authority that the school had only four and five pupils attending. Also that the school would be closed a week at a time.

This is the first complaint we have had regarding the biscuits for the R.C. School at Little Grand Rapids. We did, however, have a complaint from Luther Schuetze, teacher at the U.C. School at Little Grand Rapids, stating that the biscuits were mouldy, this we reported to the Department on January 20th, 1937.

Will you kindly refer to our letter of July 16th, 1936, in which I stated that I did not approve of Boniface Guimond being transferred from Bloodvein to Little Grand Rapids.

Your obedient servant,

E. McPherson,
Indian Agent.

R.A.Hoey.

Berens River, Man.
October 12, 1958

Reverend Father J. O. Plourde, O. M. I.,
619 McDermot Avenue,
Winnipeg, Man.

Reverend and dear Father,

Towards the later part of August, I journeyed to Little Grand Rapids to install Mr. Bellavance as teacher at the day school situated there. From that point, I went as I did last year to visit my friends the Indians of Poplar Hill. They are always in the same good dispositions. You know that they themselves asked for a day school last year. Naturally they had hopes to receive a favourable answer this year. I told them how their case stood: "The Department refuses to grant you a school because you do not live on the reserve to which you belong (Pekangigan)." The Indians answered this objection in the following way: "If we stay away at times from our reserve, it is both to our advantage and to the advantage of the Department. The Department should easily understand this. During the whole summer, there is no one on our reserve to give us employment and to help us to earn our living. Fish being our principal source of food, sometimes in fact it is all we have to eat, the supply at Pekangigan would be insufficient for the whole band. We would then have to ask for help and the government would be obliged to send us food by airplane in order to prevent us from dying from famine. This would cost a great deal. That is why we do not stay on the reserve."

I know the extreme poverty of this band of Indians and I can say that the above statement is absolutely true. I have often heard the agent say to the Indians living on other reserves, and Mr. McPherson himself has often and rightly spoken in the same vein, to go wherever they can find food. That is what the Poplar Hill band has done but on account of this the government refuses them school and their children, about thirty of school age, are growing up without any education. That is the reason why these good Indians have asked me to approach the government once more and to ask for a summer day school for at least three months, that is, June, July, August, the period of the year during which they live at Poplar Hill. During the balance of the year, they wander from place to place, trapping.
Will you be good enough, Reverend Father, to present our request once more to the Department, if Ottawa will grant the rations asked for last year (a list of which you must have in your possession) and if these rations are forwarded early next spring along with the list of tools which I forwarded at the same time as I sent you the list of rations, I will build this school myself next summer with the help of the Indians. You must remember that last year I offered to take charge of the transportation of all materials plus the rations and tools free of charge with the help of the Indians.

Mr. Bellavance who is now teaching at Little Grand Rapids could take charge of this new school on condition that the Department pay him for nine months of teaching at the latter point and three months of teaching at this new school at Poplar Hill. Mr. Bellavance to whom I have mentioned this matter would accept this arrangement quite willingly. In this manner the children of the Indians of Poplar Hill would receive some education and their parents would be quite satisfied. If this plan is accepted, it will be understood, of course, that the new school would receive the ordinary rations so that the children could be given a noon meal.

I beg to remain, Reverend and dear Father,

Yours very truly,

J. Grandpré, O. M. I.
Mr. R. A. Hoey,
Director of Welfare & Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.

My dear Mr. Hoey:

The building in which school is being taught at Little Grand Rapids, Manitoba, is an old log structure erected many years ago. It is at the present time in a most deplorable condition and was so poorly constructed that it is not worth repairing. A new building is no doubt very necessary.

As Little Grand Rapids is not easily accessible, it being about ninety miles north of Bloodvein, over a very rough territory, and as it cannot be reached in the summer except by canoe, the suggestion is made that all the material for this school should be bought next summer and stored at Bloodvein until the winter of 1939. It could then be transported to Little Grand Rapids over winter roads, and the new school could be built in the spring of 1940. That is the most economical way of proceeding.

The missionaries working in those far away districts have so much to contend with that the Department should recognize their devotion by granting these small schools wherever they are necessary. I have no doubt that your agent, Mr. McPherson, will endorse Father de Grandpré's request.

Yours very truly,

J. J. Plourde, O. M. I.

Dear Father Plourde:

I regret that it was not possible to include an item in the appropriation for the fiscal year 1939-40 for a new school at this point. However, your request will be kept in mind and if we are given an opportunity of providing funds in the supplementary estimates for new day schools careful consideration will be given to the requirements at Little Grand Rapids.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,

Dear Sir:

A request has been received for the erection of a new school to replace the present Little Grand Rapids R.C. day school. Our correspondent writes as follows:

"The building in which school is being taught at Little Grand Rapids, Manitoba, is an old log structure erected many years ago. It is at the present time in a most deplorable condition and was so poorly constructed that it is not worth repairing. A new building is no doubt very necessary.

"As Little Grand Rapids is not easily accessible, it being about ninety miles north of Bloodvein, over a very rough territory, and as it cannot be reached in the summer except by canoe, the suggestion is made that all the material for this school should be bought next summer and stored at Bloodvein until the winter of 1939. It could then be transported to Little Grand Rapids over winter roads, and the new school could be built in the spring of 1940. That is the most economical way of proceeding."

The Department is prepared to favourably consider purchase of the material required for the above building and it would be appreciated if you would let me have, as soon as possible, detailed information regarding the material required also the best method of transporting it to Bloodvein and the time of year at which it should be forwarded to that point.

In considering a new building for the Little Grand Rapids R.C. school the Department also wishes to make certain that the Little Grand Rapids U.C. school is in good condition as we want to deal fairly with both these schools.

E. McPherson, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Selkirk, Man.
You should, therefore, report fully on the present condition of the Little Grand Rapids U.C. school and if any repairs are required you should let me know giving an estimate of the cost. In the event of it being necessary to purchase materials full details should be given in order that purchase may be made by our Purchasing Branch.

An early reply to this letter will be appreciated.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Selkirk, Man., April 3rd, 1939.

Dear Sir:

This will acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 23rd instant relative to the Little Grand Rapids R.C. and U.C. Indian Day Schools.

We have written to the school teachers at Little Grand Rapids for particulars, also on my first trip up the lake I shall find out the most economical manner in which to freight in supplies next winter. This year tractors were hauling freight to Favourable Lake, Ont. to the Berens River Mines and the tractor road ran quite close to the Little Grand Rapids Reserve. It may be possible to have the transportation company at Berens River handle this freight.

As soon as we have a reply from the teachers at Little Grand we shall forward their estimates regarding the schools.

Yours very truly,

E. McPherson,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

Enclosed herewith, please find a voluminous set of requisition forms for your attention. I hesitated before sending in such a long list of items, although these are needed for the physical and intellectual welfare of my pupils.

You may rest assured that all school supplies are well taken care of; and I make it a point to see to it that my pupils do not waste any of them.

I beg to give some explanation regarding a few of the requisitioned articles:

The kettle is for cooking the beans and rice supplied for the pupils' mid-day meal.

The sugar is to sweeten the cocoa and rice, as plain boiled rice is not palatable.

One must bear in mind that the meal served at school is very often the only one the pupils receive during the whole day; therefore it is but reasonable that the food be made moderately appetizing.

The asbestos cement is for repairing the school stove which is cracked open at half a dozen places along its side, thus making it unsafe.

The barber set is for a dual purpose: to change the cave-dwelling appearance of my pupils' heads to a more modern one, and to
impose a quota on the hitherto unrestrained immigration of highly undesirable parasites.

In regard to the shipping of all merchandise and stationery for my school, may I suggest (if at all possible without interfering with the Department's wishes) that same be addressed to me, Rev. J. de Grandpré, Berens River. An allowance of $4.40 per hundredweight, covering all transportation fee from Winnipeg to my door, could be included with my cheque for September.

Shipping to the Hudson's Bay Co. and Mr. R. Schulze (both two miles from me) has proved very unsatisfactory. These parties have to wait for an opportunity to send me word that they hold a consignment for me, and I have to pay an Indian to fetch same.

In compliance with your request contained in letter of November 26th ultimo, I shall hold the annual holidays in April and May.

Yours very truly,

My dear Mr. Hoey:

I am informed that Mr. McPherson, your Agent in charge of the Little Grand Rapids Indian Reserve, told Mr. Bellavance, the teacher at the Little Grand Rapids R.C. Day School, that funds had been provided for the building of a Catholic school and that the lumber had been bought and would be shipped during the winter.

It seems that the lumber was actually bought and freighted to the Little Grand Rapids Reserve; but instead of being delivered to the Catholic school, it was delivered to the non-Catholic school. It is rumoured that this lumber will be used for the building of the non-Catholic Day School instead of the Catholic Day School as Mr. Bellavance was informed by your Agent.

I would like to know if there has been a mistake in this matter and what steps will be taken to insure that the lumber bought for the Catholic school will be used for the purpose originally intended. The information which I have given you above was brought to me yesterday by Rev. Father de Grandpré who is in charge of the Berens River District, which also combines Bloodvein and Little Grand Rapids.

I wish to say that the above inquiry is not intended as criticism of the Department. I simply wish to know what the Department intends to do for the R.C. Indian Day School at Little Grand Rapids.

Yours very truly,

W.H.G. Gibbs, M.D., C.M.
Selkirk, Man., Oct. 15, 1940.

Dear Sirs:

I beg to report having made a special trip and visit to Little Grand Rapids Reserve.

At R.C. school the teacher is busy fixing up and repairing the old school, the lower logs are very badly rotted but they are trying to make it habitable for this winter. This week Mr. Street intends repairing and fixing up the protestant school.

I would like to make a suggestion that this winter logs be taken out to build two new schools. There is at present time on the reserve nearly enough lumber and material, provided logs where used to build both schools, which was shipped in last winter by tractor it would require very little additional material to make both schools. The condition of both these schools is such that they should be replaced by new ones next summer especially for the health of the children.

W.H.G. Gibbs, M.D., C.M.

The Secretary,

Ottawa.

Re: New Day School and teachers' Residence at Little Grand Rapids.

Attention: Mr. Phelan.

My dear Mr. Phelan:

May I call your attention to the present condition of the above school and teachers' residence. Both should be replaced and as I have already written to you about this matter, I hope that the necessary amount has been included in the coming estimates.

The last report I have from Reverend Father de Grandpré, O.M.I., Missionary in charge of Little Grand Rapids, shows 38 children, 18 boys and 20 girls, attending this school. The building contemplated should, therefore, be large enough for about 50 children and the teachers' residence should be so constructed and furnished as to make the living in that far-off country as agreeable as possible.

Reverend Father de Grandpré has again written to me about this matter and I would like to have something in writing that I could forward to him. It will serve as an encouragement in the very difficult task that he is performing, in that faraway country.

Yours very truly,

J.O. Plourde, O.M.I.

Memorandum:

DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT

Re: Building Material for School at Little Grand Rapids, Manitoba

We are in receipt of your memorandum of September 26th with reference to our requisition of September 12th. It is noted that you have been unable to obtain quotations from several firms including Brown and Rutherford Limited.

Rev. J.O. Plourde, O.M.I., interviewed Mr. Brown in Winnipeg about six weeks ago and at that time Mr. Brown intimated to him that there was such a heavy demand for building material that the firm was not answering requests for quotations as they could sell all material they obtained. However, Mr. Brown told Father Plourde that in view of the long association of the Oblate Order with the firm of Brown & Rutherford, they would be prepared to supply the materials for the Little Grand Rapids School even though it meant disappointing other customers.

It is pointed out in memorandum of September 12th, that the material should be purchased this year if at all possible so that the erection of the building can be accomplished during the summer of 1942. If purchase is delayed until next spring it will probably mean that the building could not be erected before 1943. With the above in mind, it is recommended an order be sent immediately to Brown & Rutherford. Judging from the reputation of the firm as outlined by Father Plourde, it is felt that they will not overcharge.

Director,

DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT

Re: Little Grand Rapids R.C. Day School No. 524

In the current year's appropriation provision was made for the erection of a new school at Little Grand Rapids Reserve. If the material can be purchased this year the school can be erected next year. Otherwise, the erection of the school would be delayed until 1948.

We are advised that Brown and Rutherford Lumber Dealers, Winnipeg, Manitoba, have all or nearly all of the items mentioned on this requisition. Memorandum:

DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT

Re: Building Material for School at Little Grand Rapids, Manitoba

We are in receipt of your memorandum of September 26th with reference to our requisition of September 12th. It is noted that you have been unable to obtain quotations from several firms including Brown and Rutherford Limited.

Rev. J.O. Plourde, O.M.I., interviewed Mr. Brown in Winnipeg about six weeks ago and at that time Mr. Brown intimated to him that there was such a heavy demand for building material that the firm was not answering requests for quotations as they could sell all material they obtained. However, Mr. Brown told Father Plourde that in view of the long association of the Oblate Order with the firm of Brown & Rutherford, they would be prepared to supply the materials for the Little Grand Rapids School even though it meant disappointing other customers.

It is pointed out in memorandum of September 12th, that the material should be purchased this year if at all possible so that the erection of the building can be accomplished during the summer of 1942. If purchase is delayed until next spring it will probably mean that the building could not be erected before 1943. With the above in mind, it is recommended an order be sent immediately to Brown & Rutherford. Judging from the reputation of the firm as outlined by Father Plourde, it is felt that they will not overcharge.

Director.
Ottawa, 1 November 1946.

Little Grand Rapids Day School R.C.

This school was built a year ago and the teacher's residence and the school are separate buildings. They are both fine buildings with insulated brick siding and very nice and clean.

Most Reverend Sir,

It is regretted very much that the Department finds it necessary to call Your Grace's attention to the matter of the appointment of a teacher for the Little Saskatchewan Indian school.

On October 26th, last, the Department wrote Venerable Archdeacon Phair offering to increase the salary at this school from $300.00 to $500.00 per annum for a trained teacher. Dear Mr. Maclean:

Archdeacon Phair has handed me your letter of Nov. 25th, re the appointment of Mr. J. P. Anderson to the school at Sandy Bay. On November 12th, I had a letter from the Rev. George Bruce, in which he stated that the chief at Sandy Bay had asked for the appointment of Mr. Anderson as teacher and also enclosed a list of the names of those who approved of his appointment.

I know nothing of the man and have been consequently unable to give my approval of his appointment, but I have informed Mr. Bruce of the attitude of the Department in regard to it. This is all I can do at present. The appointment, I understand, is only a temporary one, until some more competent teacher can be secured. I may say that we find it quite impossible to secure competent teachers at the salary offered by the Indian Department. Unless the salary is considerably raised, it is hopeless to think of securing teachers to fill these schools.

I enclose a petition which has come from the Dog Creek Indians for an additional school at that point, together with a list of the children who would be likely to attend it. Kindly let me know what action the Department is likely to take in regard to this. The whole question of the services of Day School teachers should be taken up. Can you kindly let me know whether any steps are being taken towards establishing a school at the new reserve at Fisher River?

With kind regards, I am,

Very sincerely yours,

Dear Mr. McLean:

I am in receipt of yours of Dec. 14th. A letter of mine written last Saturday will have crossed yours.

I had not heard anything from Archdeacon Phair in regard to the school at Sandy Bay till I sent for him on Friday night last and showed him the correspondence with Rev. Mr. Bruce. The Archdeacon is becoming an old man and I fear that he is losing his memory. It will be better for the future to correspond with me direct in regard to school matters.

I had not heard that the Department had consented to raise the salary to $500. I shall at once make enquiries as to the possibility of securing a teacher at that amount, but it is very doubtful whether I can obtain one who is competent, even at that figure. Common day schools in Manitoba have raised the salary of teachers to $600 and $700 a year and there is a great dearth of suitable ones at the present time. However, I will do my best to secure somebody. In the meantime, what had better be done in regard to John Peter Anderson. If the Department disapproves of him, as it is clear from your letter, he had better be notified at once to sever his connection with the school. Mr. Bruce sent me a long list of names of those who profess to be favorable to his taking up the work, but I have no desire to press him upon the Department if he is unsuitable, as I know nothing at all about him.

With kind regards, I am,

Very sincerely yours,

Dear Mr. Mr. McLean,

I am in receipt of yours of Feb. 4th No. 117648—I re the school at Little Saskatchewan. For two reasons I have been unable to procure a teacher for that school. In the first place the band appear to be divided as to whether they want a new teacher or whether they wish to retain Anderson. At one time they wrote me that they desire a change and within a few days they retract what they have written. When the chief and councillors were in Winnipeg in July I asked on their return to summon a meeting and let me know what they really wanted. They have never done so. In the second place there is no place at Little Saskatchewan for the teacher to live. For these reasons I have been unable to do anything but I am writing to the Chief today about the matter and will let you know what reply he gives. Even when the two difficulties which I have referred to have been removed, I am not very hopeful of securing a competent teacher. The salary offered is too small. A short time ago I advertised for teachers for our Indian Schools at the Sioux Mission etc. but no one would entertain the offer after the salary was mentioned. The fact is, the Department will have to offer more to these teachers or the schools will remain vacant. I am hoping to be in Ottawa in Apr 1 and will be glad to go into these and other matters with you. Yours very truly

Dear Mr. Scott,

I have in prospect a very good man, an educated Englishman, for the School at Little Saskatchewan but I fear that I cannot secure him at the usual salary of $300. Is it possible for the Department to offer him more? He is a friend of the two very good men whom we have now at the two Schools at Peguis. Kindly let me know what you can do. Rupert Bruce is still in charge of the School at Upper Fairford though his father has retired from the Mission and a new man has been placed in charge, Rev. T.H. Dobbs, formerly of Shell River. What about the effort to establish an improved Day School at Fairford? You will remember that you were to look into it before the Estimates were made up. Now that Mr. Bruce is not there I believe that the Indians can be persuaded to accept an Improved School particularly if they are told definitely that the Department has no intention of giving them a Boarding School. The trouble in the past has been that they were always given to understand by the Agents that the Department was ready to give the Boarding School but that the Bishop held it back. They even were given the impression that my predecessor had used for his own purposes the $28,500 voted by the Government for the purpose in Mr. Sifton's time. As I stated in a former letter, I am willing to accompany any one whom the Dept. decides to send and use my influence with the Band.

Wishing you all the blessings of this Season, I am very sincerely yours,

D.C. Scott, Esq.

Sir:

I enclose copy of a petition received from a number of the Indians of the Little Saskatchewan reserve, requesting the establishment of a day school at Dauphin River Hatchery.

Sir:

Re: 126-8-1, Ottawa, April 10th, 1935.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of the above noted letter, regarding the establishing of a day school at Dauphin River Hatchery Reserve No. 48A.

The Hatchery Reserve is known as No. 48A, and is known as the old Little Saskatchewan Reserve. A list is attached hereto showing the children of school age. All the people shown on the list are permanent residents at the Hatchery with the exception of Chas. Sumner. This Indian is resident during the winter months. The reserve is located on Lake Winnipeg at the mouth of the Dauphin River. It is a fishing station, the Provincial Government using the river as a Whitefish spawn fishing station during the fall run of the Whitefish. It is approximately 50 miles from the nearest railroad station—Gypsumville—the roads being impassible during the summer months, small boats being used on the Dauphin River. This point can also be approached from Selkirk, the Government boat making it a point of call two or three times a year. During the winter months it is a point of call for teams freighting fish from the lake, and during the commercial fishing season—which commences January 1st until the close March 20th—the Indian fishermen from Fairford, Little Saskatchewan and Lake St. Martin reserves, camp there with their families. The few residents on the reserve during the summer months does not warrant the building of a day school. During the winter season, a number of school children are on the reserve with their parents. Of recent years the number has decreased, as fishing has not been so good, and Indians have arranged with people living on the Lake Reserves to take care of their children, so that they could attend the school.

The permanent residents of the Hatchery are "Shakers". They have erected a church from collections amongst themselves and transient Indians, a member of the Band Holds service. Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6240, file 525-3, part 1)
Sir,-

In reference to your letter of the 28th ultimo, No.126-8-3.

No doubt that Mr. Wheadon was on the Reserve on the 1st November, but there was no reason why he did not open school on the 1st November. I admit that the new building was not ready, but the old building was there and he could have held his classes in the old building, until the new one was ready.

I do not consider that Mr. Wheadon has any claim on the Department for the first part of November.

Your obedient servant,

The Asst. Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6240, file 525-3, part 1)
Ottawa, March 10, 1925.

Sir,

In further reference to your letter of the 20th ultimo, I beg to say that the Department has made enquiries regarding your request for salary from the first of November last, and it has been found that, while the new school was not ready still, the old building was there and it would have been possible to conduct the school in that building until the new one was ready.

As the classes were not commenced until the 17th of November it is regretted that payment cannot be made to you from November 1st.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Perrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

A. Wheadon, Esq.,
Gypsumville,
MAN.

Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY.

Re: Little Saskatchewan Indian Day School No. 525

The Department has received and accepted the resignation of Mr. A. Wheeldon as teacher of the above school effective July 1, 1946 and no further payment of salary should be made after that date.

Bernard F. Neary,
for Deputy Head.
Ottawa, August 20, 1946.

Most Reverend Sir:

I have for answer your letter of August 16. The Department has authorized the appointment of Mr. George Basham as teacher of the Little Saskatchewan Indian Day School at a salary of $95.00 per teaching month plus bonus of $4.15.

I have written to Mr. J. Waite, Indian Agent, Portage la Prairie, informing him of this appointment.

I have also written to Mr. Basham, enclosing the usual forms for completion.

Very sincerely yours,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Most Reverend L. R. Sherman, M.A., B.Litt., D.D.,
Archbishop of Rupert's Land,
Synod Office, Trinity Hall,
Winnipeg, Manitoba.
Ottawa, 19 November 1946.

Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY

Re: Little Saskatchewan Indian Day School No. 525

Mr. George Basham has been appointed teacher of this school at a salary of $118.00 a teaching month effective Sept. 1, 1946.

He has forwarded staff questionnaire form which will reach you shortly but he has not yet forwarded a T.D. 1 form. We are again writing to him to obtain this form. In the meantime, it would be appreciated if you would arrange to forward him a cheque for the amount due him for the months of September and October classing him as a single man without dependents until we receive further information.

Sir:

Miss K. C. Weber is in charge and is a Normal trained teacher. The roll calls for 25 and I found 10 present. The average for last quarter was 20.4. The grades are arranged as follows:

Grade I - 17
" II - 4

The children were tidy, but poorly clad. The reading was fair and I found the work neatly set down in their exercise books. The pupils appeared well along in their various grades.

The school is of modern design and in good repair. The interior is badly in need of decoration as the rooms are now very dull and gloomy.

Biscuits are supplied as a noon lunch.

Miss Weber has as her assistant Mrs. L. Vaudry who also has charge of the drugs. Mrs. Vaudry also does considerable field matron work.

Sir:

I beg to enclose requisition for school material received from Mr. A. Wheadon, Teacher, Little Saskatchewan Day School, in which he asks for eavestroughing for the teacherage.

This eavestroughing is very necessary as the water from the roof is washing the foundations of the house, and leaking into the cellar, making it impossible to keep vegetables, and the house warm during the winter.

The approximate cost of this eavestroughing f.o.b. Winnipeg will be $15.00, solder 1.00, there will be an additional cost of freighting. The teacher will do the work of erecting free of cost to the Department.

Ottawa, October 25, 1937.

Dear Sir:

The Department is considering in the Estimates for 1938-39, provision for a new one-room Day School on the Little Saskatchewan Indian Reserve.

In order that we may have full information, I would appreciate an early reply to the following questions:

(1) The approximate number of children for which provision should be made.

(2) Is the site available, or will it be necessary to purchase a site? In either event, you should state the size of the site you consider necessary and the general condition of the land, viz: whether level or sloping. You should also mention the direction in which you consider the building should face.

(3) Will it be necessary to provide living quarters for the teacher, in connection with the School?

(4) Can drinking water be easily obtained on the site recommended by you?

(5) Would you recommend construction by contract or by day labour?

(6) Do you consider a full basement advisable?
In addition to the information requested above, you should also give any particulars that would assist the Department in planning the building. It is hoped that your reply will be both detailed and definite, in order that further correspondence will not be necessary.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

S. J. Waite, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Portage la Prairie,
Manitoba.
Sir,

Re 126-8-5.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 25th ultimo re the building of a new one room school on the Little Saskatchewan Reserve. In reply to this letter I beg to submit the following information:

No.1. Provision should be made for 35 children.

No.2. Site is available on the reserve adjacent to the site of the old school now being used. The land is level. The school should be faced to the road which runs north and south. About two acres of school lands are now fenced.

No.3. A teacherage was built on the school site ten years ago. This is in excellent repair.

No.4. Drinking water has always been obtained from Lake St. Martin. A distance of approximately 400 yards to the shore line. I am doubtful if good drinking water could be obtained by sinking a well. A shallow well would only give surface water, and a deep well alkali water.

No.5. I would recommend the job be done by contract, Indians to be employed as helpers etc.

No.6. I would strongly recommend a full basement with a furnace for heating purposes. This gives room for storage and does away with a heater in the centre of the schoolroom floor. It is also less dangerous than the stove method of heating, and gives more room in the schoolroom.

The old school-house is built of logs. A log building is a continual nuisance. During the winter the slamming of the door loosens the chinking and it is continually dropping out causing replacements and a cold school. It also seems impossible to make whitewash stick to logs and this is for ever peeling.

Peeling off leaving the floor in an unswept condition. I would strongly suggest that the new school be of frame construction. A midday meal is provided for the pupils from November to April and I also suggest that provision be made to accommodate the pupils in the basement during the eating of the meal.

There is sufficient wood fuel for some years to come and a wood furnace should be installed.

I might state that the site is not owned by the Department, and I am very doubtful if the Indians of this reserve would give the Department title.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, December 2, 1937.

Dear Sir:

The Department is in receipt of your letter of November 18th, with reference to the proposed new school on the Little Saskatchewan Reserve. In Paragraph No. 2 of your letter, you state that "site is available on the Reserve adjacent to the site of the old school now being used", but in the last paragraph of your letter you state that "the site is not owned by the Department and I am very doubtful if the Indians of this Reserve would give the Department title".

These two statements appear contradictory and I would appreciate your advising the size of the site on which the present school is located and if it would be possible to erect a new school on this site.

You might also give a description of the nature of the soil as this information is required in order to decide if a basement could be provided at a reasonable cost.

In the event of our deciding to erect the school by day labour, you should let me know the nearest railway point to the school and the distance of this railway station from the school. What would it cost per day to hire trucks to transport the material from the station to the school site.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

J. Waite, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Portage la Prairie,
Manitoba.
Sir,

Re: 126-8-5.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 2nd instant, and wish to advise that the fenced school plot is approximately two acres. It would be possible to erect the new school on the old school site, but I would not recommend it as the old school is too close to the main road. I would suggest that the new school be built about 30 yards east of the old school. I attach a diagram showing the fenced plot.

The soil is of a sandy nature for about 8 inches, very stoney, the subsoil, "hardpan". This "hardpan" is of the usual texture found in the Inter-lake district, and borders on cement. In asking for a basement to the school, I am certain this form of construction would be the cheaper in the long-run.

St. Martin is the nearest railway point. Gypsumville the most convenient from a road standpoint. The haul from Gypsumville would be approximately ten miles. There are no trucks in the district and at this time I am not able to give an estimate of the cost of transporting materials. I believe hauling could be done cheaper by hiring Indian teams. It would also give the Indians of the three Lake Reserves work. Another point in favour of having shipments sent to Gypsumville, is that there is a resident R.R.Agent.

Your obedient servant,

NAME OF BUILDING: LITTLE SASKATCHEWAN INDIAN DAY SCHOOL.

RECOMMEND CONSTRUCTION BY: DAY LABOUR

BUILDING REQUIREMENTS: ROOMS AND ACCOMMODATION; NUMBER OF PUPILS;

TYPE OF CONSTRUCTION:

DESCRIPTION OF SITE AND CONDITIONS; SUBMIT PLAN; NORTH POINT;

NATURE OF SOIL, DRAINAGE REQUIREMENTS AND ANY OTHER PARTICULARS.

The soil is of a sandy nature for about 5 inches, and very stony, the subsoil "hardpan". This "hardpan" is of the usual texture found in the Inter-lake district and borders on cement. The building should face East.

HEATING SYSTEM: TYPE OF FURNACE OR BOILER; FUEL.

LIGHTING SYSTEM: SOURCE OF POWER; SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS.

BUILT-IN EQUIPMENT REQUIRED: BLACKBOARD AREA; CUPBOARDS, ETC.

Blackboard on front and along one side.

SHIPPING INSTRUCTIONS FOR MATERIALS: NEAREST SHIPPING POINT

LOCAL TRANSPORTATION FACILITIES TO SITE, ETC.

St. Martin is the nearest railway point. Gypsumville the most convenient from a road standpoint. The haul from Gypsumville would be approximately ten miles. There are no trucks in the district and at this time I am not able to give an estimate of the cost of transporting materials. I believe hauling could be done cheaper by hiring Indian teams. Memorandum:

Dr. McGill

Re: Proposed new day school, Little Saskatchewan Indian Reserve, Manitoba.

As requested in your memorandum of the 3rd instant, I am enclosing herewith, in duplicate, a blue line print of sketch plan (design A.7) for the above building.

It will be noted that while this type of school has previously been designed with a verandah across the entrance front, this feature has been eliminated and grade entrances introduced as a saving in cost. These entrances obviate the risk of slippery steps and that on the boys' side serves also as a grade entrance to the basement.

The estimated cost of this building with classroom for 36 pupils is $5,700.00 or with classroom for 42 pupils $6,000.00.

An additional amount of about $200.00 would be required to cover the cost of outside toilets making a total amount of $5,900.00 or $6,200.00 according to whether accommodation is required for 36 or 42 pupils respectively.
Will you please look this plan over and return one set duly signed, with any comments you desire to make.

Memorandum:

Mr. Wardle

Re - Proposed Day School, Little Saskatchewan Indian Reserve, Manitoba.

I am in receipt of your memorandum of the 30th ultimo regarding the cost of the above school.

The previous estimate of $5,700.00 was based on preliminary sketch plans and costs of similar work with slight increase to cover advance in cost of materials and wages. Since then in working out the detail drawings some economies have been possible and it is estimated that this structure can be built for about $5000.00.

In regard to the second paragraph of your letter regarding only $3,500.00 being listed for the building in the breakdown of the item of $56,000.00 our understanding is that the tentative allocation of funds was made by the Indian Affairs Branch for their 1938-39 Estimates without regard in some cases to the amount necessary to provide accommodation to meet their requirements. It is suggested that the Indian Affairs Branch after consultation with our officers furnish a list giving reallocation of funds in line with school requirements.

The school is of simple design and construction and embodies the accommodation and requirements asked by the Indian Affairs Branch.

Respectfully submitted,

J. M. Wardle, Esq.,

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER:

Re - Little Saskatchewan Indian Day School

I have for acknowledgment Mr. Pratt's memorandum of February 7, with respect to the construction of the above noted school.

Provision was made in the 1938-39 estimates for the construction of this school. In official letter dated October 25, 1937, Indian Agent Waite was asked to submit for departmental consideration the information ordinarily requested from Indian agents with respect to the construction of such buildings. In reply the Indian Agent stated:

1. Provision should be made for 35 children.

2. A site is available on the reserve adjacent to the site of the old school now being used.

3. A teacherage was built on the school site 10 years ago and is in excellent repair.

4. Drinking water can be obtained from Lake St. Martin, a distance of approximately 400 yards.

5. I would recommend that the job be done by contract, Indians to be employed as helpers, etc.

6. I would strongly recommend a full basement with a furnace for heating purposes. This gives room for storage and does away with a heater in the centre of the schoolroom floor. It is also less dangerous than the stove.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6240, file 525-5, part 3)
stove method of heating and gives more room in the classroom.

7. A midday meal is provided for the pupils from November to April, and I recommend that provision be made to accommodate the pupils in the basement during the serving and eating of this meal".

It has been the policy of the Department in recent years to provide full basement accommodation at Indian day schools. Such accommodation is an absolute necessity if vocational instruction is to form part of the regular course of study provided. Basement accommodation is also necessary where noonday lunches are provided.

The construction of this school, with accommodation for 36 pupils, was undertaken by the Surveys and Engineering Branch and the work was performed by contract. Mr. Wardle, in a report dated January 13, 1929, states:

"The total amount paid the contractor is $4,761. There will be in addition certain miscellaneous departmental expenditures chargeable to the work. Final figures will be given you in due course".

These final figures have not been submitted to this Branch. It will be noted, however, that the cost compares very favourably with the cost of Indian day schools constructed in recent years.

The Public School Inspector, in his report dated November 22, 1929, states:

"I was very favourably impressed with the new building you have erected during the course of the summer at Little Saskatchewan reserve, which in my judgment is certainly a credit to your Department".
The last census indicates that there is an Indian population at the Little Saskatchewan reserve of 184 with 25 Indian children under 7 years old and 30 children between the ages of 7 and 16.

I am sending forward herewith the photographs of the school received by this Branch, which I should like returned at your convenience.

Director.

Sept. 8, 1943.

The Secretary, Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

The old school at Little Saskatchewan Reserve, built of logs, is gradually depreciating and is spoiling the appearance of the school grounds. The school is of little value and might be disposed of for a little cash to one of the Indians of the reserve. Will you please advise if I may dispose of this school.

J. Waite,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
September 15, 1943.

Mr. J. Waite, Indian Agent, Portage la Prairie, Man.

I have your letter of the 8th instant, applying for permission to sell the old log school on the Little Saskatchewan Reserve. We will have to submit this matter to the Salvage Officer, but before doing so I would like you to state to whom you think you could sell the building and the approximate amount which you consider could be obtained.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Portage la Prairie,
Manitoba.

November 23, 1943.

The Secretary, Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Re: 126-8-5, Ottawa, September 15, 1943.

In reply to the above noted letter, I wish to advise that the school on the Little Sask. Reserve is worth in the neighbourhood of $35 - $40. A price close to the amounts stated could be obtained, in fact, several offers submitted by Indians has been made. The trouble is to obtain cash. I beg to suggest that the order for the sale of the building be obtained from the Salvage Officer and the building may then be sold during the fishing season at a time when the Indians have a little surplus cash.

J. Waite,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
November 27, 1943.

DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT

Re: Little Saskatchewan Indian Reserve,

the above reserve, which is not being used, was

been submitted by Indians. The trouble is to obtain

from the Salvage Officer to sell this building and

With reference to requisition of the last instant, you may purchase 1½ gallons of ground colour, 3½ gallons enamel and 2 pounds wall sizing for decorating some of the rooms in the teacher's living quarters at the Little Saskatchewan Indian Day School. Regarding the painting of the roof, the Department does not see any necessity for purchasing lumber for a scaffold. The building is not sufficiently high to require a scaffold. I note that you suggest shingle stain. Recently the Department remodelled a school in Quebec and the following mixture was used instead of shingle stain:

1 Pint of Japan drier
6 Lbs. of ochre (green or red)
3 Gals. of used cylinder oil
(Let oil rest in order to clear)

Multiply these proportions by 4 and add ½ gal. linseed oil.
Mix well and let stand for a day.

A quantity of the mixture mentioned can be obtained at a great deal less cost than the shingle stain and we have found by experience that it is more durable.

May 28, 1946.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

The school fence, Little Saskatchewan Reserve, is in a delapidated condition and all the posts should be renewed. The fence has been up for almost twenty years and from time to time the posts have been re-sharpened and braces replaced. Approximately 400 fence posts are required at a cost of .10¢ each, braces will also cost the same. Labour for the erection of the fence will cost in the neighbourhood of $20.00. Total cost, $60.00.

If this work is approved, I would be pleased to receive an accountable cheque in an amount of $20.00 to pay for labour, which will be done by Indians.

The site of the old school, also on the Little Saskatchewan Reserve, should be filled in and levelled. It is an eyesore in its present condition. The approximate cost of this work would be $10.00.

J. White,
Indian Agent.

Mr. J. Waite, Indian Agent,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

May 20, 1927.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I wish to refer to your 208-7 B of October 20th, 1925, and your 208-11 A of the first item, concerning the advisability of erecting a teacher's residence at the Little Saskatchewan Indian Day School. I am pleased to inform you that funds are now available for this purpose and you may proceed with the work. You estimated the cost to be approximately $2,200 and I should be glad to learn that the expense will not be more than this amount. I regret there are no funds this year for a similar building activity at the Lake St. Martin Indian Day School.

It has been suggested that a kitchen for the preparation of the pupils' midday meal be provided at the Little Saskatchewan School. Please look into the advisability of providing such a room in the new building. If it can be included without materially adding to the cost and you consider it necessary, you should make arrangements.

I understand that a porch should be added to the classroom at this school and that the playground and garden should be fenced. If you are satisfied that these improvements are required, you may proceed with the work.

Please be guided by general instructions in Dr. Scott's 1-1-5 of the 6th instant.

Yours very truly,

J. D. McLean,
Acting Deputy Superintendent General.

REGINA, Sask.

May incur extra expenditure three hundred dollars erection teacher's residence Little Saskatchewan school.

Chg. Dept. I. A. J. D. McLEAN.
Dear Sir,

Mr. Wheaden, teacher of the Indian Day School on the Little Saskatchewan Reserve, Portage Agency, called last week re the need of a bed, spring and mattress.

Mr. Wheaden pointed out that they have their own bedroom furnished but when the Nurse arrives or any other official they are obliged to give up their room and then must use cots; which is inconvenient and uncomfortable. The Nurse remains for eight or ten days each month; consequently there is a real need for a spare bed. I have been accommodated at this same home and never knew until now I had the only bed.

I would recommend a complete bed unit be supplied. Batons state this will cost from $25.00 to $30.00. The bedding companies have passed their quota and if secured from them a priority rating is required.

I would like authority to make the purchase at once from the T.Eaton Company and will endeavour not to exceed $30.00. The size required is a 4 ft. bed, complete with high riser spring and well-constructed cotton filled mattress.

Yours very truly,

A.G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies for Manitoba.

Dear Mr. Pedley,

I am writing an urgent request, and hope you will be able to grant it, or have it granted by the D.O. I will say at the outset that it is a special case, not considered as such; that is, it will not consider it as a precedent, or as affecting the general principle that I have already laid before you of paying half-teaching expenses of first teachers in their school district.

Mr. W.C. Lundy has taught day-school at Morse Lake for over a year. The Inspector at his last visit, while not altogether approving of the result yet said he lay all the blame on Lundy, but said that the Indians did not like him, & that he wished him moved to another school (I have Mr. Laird's letter to this effect). The nearest vacant one was Shovel Lake, some 10 days or a fortnight's travel. Lundy had to take wife & family household goods, & he says that the journey cost $56 (his planoe & boat etc.) But unhappily, on the way, his canoe upset in a bad rapid. One little girl was drowned, his boy...
escaped is almost a miracle, everything went to the bottom. Shoes, pans, guns, traps, clothes, food, etc. After some hard work and privation they reached More Lake, little but almost starving. What is the date, with winter coming in, almost everything he possessed gone?

I have sent him $50 meanwhile, but we really can not afford it, our funds for Indi work are overdrawn now.

I told him that I could not afford this, but he must have it, so I would try to get that $50 returned, another sum added. First there is the $50 for the journey, then the money required for property lost. Can you not forward me $75 or $100, out of which I can return the Church funds all or part of the $50 advanced, and give the rest to him in further aid?

He did his work for us at More Lake fairly well, and it was at the Inspector's request per Hon. D. Laird that he was moved—trying for a favorable reply.

Sincerely,

J. A. Saskatchewan

Dear Sir:

Moose Lake School: (a) In accordance with your request of some time ago, I have had the repairs of the school attended to. (b) Mr. E. Constant notified me that he was giving up the school in Sept. I looked in vain for someone to take his place. But Mr. Lamb, a trader, and a former teacher, brought a Mr. C.T. Mitchell to my missionary, Rev. A. Fraser and recommended him for teacher. Mr. Mitchell only promises to take it till June next. He is an American Protestant and promises to "try to fill all the requirements of Church I.D." and to begin at once. I know nothing of him except that Mr. Lamb recommends him, and I have found Mr. Lamb reliable and good to the Indians. It is not the most satisfactory way of filling the appointment, but I have no other in view. I have desired my missionary to watch most carefully and report the first sign of trouble or inefficiency. I would request your Department to give him a trial and to notify him to that effect. Address to Mr. C.T. Mitchell, c/o Mr. W. Lamb, Moose Lake, c/o The Pas.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of Department letter No. 119408/1 dated Feb. 2nd. re Moose Lake School.

While there on Feb. 2nd. I had the Chief call a Band meeting, 21 men being present, to discuss the School situation, and they were unanimous in demanding that their school be re-opened. They have no complaint or fault to find with the Public School, and their only reason is that when their treaty was made they were promised a School and they want it. I explained to them that the Public School was only a hundred yards from their school, was a well built modern school with a qualified teacher, something they did not have in their own school. They acknowledged all this, but absolutely refused to send their children.

On my return I received the Department's letter No. 119408/1 dated Jan. 20th. and wrote the Chief accordingly, and also to Mr. Lamb requesting him to advise me of any action taken.

Notes made on a visit to the Moose Lake Indian Day School, on Monday June the 9th, 1919.

I inspected the Moose Lake Consolidated Day School on Monday June the 9th, and found Miss Margery Burrows acting as the Teacher. This young woman was educated in London England, and has a Board of Education Certificate, from that City.

She holds a 2nd-class certificate from the Province of Manitoba, and has Normal training. She taught for one year in England, 1 year in Alberta, and 6 years in Manitoba.

I found on the roll of the School the names of 31 Indian Children, 9 Girls and 12 Boys.

There were present at the inspection, 6 girls and 7 boys, all of whom were in standard 1.

There were 5 girls and 5 boys in the A.B.C. class, and all they knew is to point out the letters of the Alphabet, and they are very slow at that, they know the figures, and can count up to 50, they are learning to make words on their slates.

The senior class of the first Standard, 2 boys and 1 girl read a very little in the first reader, and are very poor at spelling, they can do small sums in addition, and could write their names on the blackboard.

The pupils of this school have made no progress since my last inspection, and the Band complained that their children can not get along with the white children, who also attend this school. I looked into this and found that there was really no foundation for this complaint. Most of the other children, small Indian children who attend, are non-treaty children, and a great many are related to the Indian Children. The real trouble is the very irregular attendance of the Indian Children, and this accounts for their lack of progress. Miss Burrows tells me that she finds it very difficult teaching at this school, on account of the lack of knowledge of the Indian language, and the irregular attendance.

Right Reverend Sir:

With reference to the Moose Lake Public School, which was discussed at the time of Your Lordship's recent visit to Ottawa, I have to inform you that the arrangements have been made in the past with the Manitoba Department of Education. When Indian children in the Prairie Provinces attend a public school, the Department allows a per capita grant of $20 per annum, based on the actual attendance.

In former years, the Manitoba Department of Education and this Department conducted at Moose Lake a combined white and Indian school and the Department of Indian Affairs paid half the costs. The Indian parents took no interest in the education of their children and the attendance was so irregular and unsatisfactory that the Department discontinued support and responsibility. The Moose Lake School is now a public one, and if Indian children attend, the Department will allow the trustees the per capita grant of $20.

Sir:

The Indians attending the school are three boys and five girls; all these are in Standard one. About all I could say for the benefit this school is doing to the Indian children is probably keeping them away from home where they might get in the way of their parents. It is practically impossible for Indians at Moose Lake to send their children to school more than half time, as their mode of making a living takes them away from home most of the time.

When I was in the school I took notice of the work being done by the white children and half-breeds who are attending regularly and they are getting on as well as children of the same age in Town here. Dear Sir:

My view of the situation is that we will always have trouble there as long as the church deducts the teachers salary from stipend of the missionary. When we have a teacher acting as lay reader at reserves it is not so bad, but when we place a missionary as teacher they get dissatisfied.

I beg to nominate as his successor at Moose Lake Mr Charles Eric Littler who hold a First Class Professional Certificate (No 64484) in the Province of Manitoba, and who is prepared to take up the duties of the office as soon as your approval, and that of the Department of Education in Winnipeg, is received.

On account of weather conditions and the long journey by water to Moose Lake, I earnestly trust that a decision may speedily be reached.

I am,

Faithfully yours.

[Signature]

Bishop of Brandon.
Ottawa, October 2, 1934.

Right Reverend Sir:

I have Your Lordship's letter of the 26th ultimo, nominating the services of Mr. Charles Eric Littler to succeed Mr. Harold Newton as teacher of the Moose Lake Combined white and Indian Day School.

In reply I have to say that, as far as the Department is concerned, the appointment of Mr. Littler will be satisfactory. As you are, no doubt, aware, this Department allows as its share of the salary a grant for the teaching of the Indian children only, at the rate of $35.00 per teaching month.

I have the honour to be,

Right Reverend Sir,

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Right Rev. Wilfrid Thomas, D.D.,
Bishop of Brandon,
Brandon, Man.
CLOSED
